Appendix A.1.24 <del>

<del> (deletion) contains a letter, word, or passage deleted, marked as deleted, or otherwise indicated as superfluous or spurious in the copy text by an author, scribe, or a previous annotator or corrector. [3.4.3. Additions, Deletions, and Omissions]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.dimensions (@unit, @quantity, @extent) (att.ranging (@atLeast, @atMost, @min, @max)) att.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
Member of
model.pPart.transcriptional
Contained by
core: q
msdescription: rubric
May containCharacter data only
Note

This element should be used for deletion of shorter sequences of text, typically single words or phrases. The <delSpan> element should be used for longer sequences of text, for those containing structural subdivisions, and for those containing overlapping additions and deletions.

The text deleted must be at least partially legible in order for the encoder to be able to transcribe it (unless it is restored in a <supplied> tag). Illegible or lost text within a deletion may be marked using the <gap/> tag to signal that text is present but has not been transcribed, or is no longer visible. Attributes on the <gap/> element may be used to indicate how much text is omitted, the reason for omitting it, etc. If text is not fully legible, the <unclear/> element (available when using the additional tagset for transcription of primary sources) should be used to signal the areas of text which cannot be read with confidence in a similar way.

Degrees of uncertainty over what can still be read, or whether a deletion was intended may be indicated by use of the <certainty> element (see 21. Certainty, Precision, and Responsibility).

There is a clear distinction in the TEI between <del> and <surplus> on the one hand and <gap/> or <unclear/> on the other. <del> indicates a deletion present in the source being transcribed, which states the author's or a later scribe's intent to cancel or remove text. <surplus> indicates material present in the source being transcribed which should have been so deleted, but which is not in fact. <gap/> or <unclear/>, by contrast, signal an editor's or encoder's decision to omit something or their inability to read the source text. See sections 11.3.1.7. Text Omitted from or Supplied in the Transcription and 11.3.3.2. Use of the gap, del, damage, unclear, and supplied Elements in Combination for the relationship between these and other related elements used in detailed transcription.

Example
<rubricÂ xml:lang="grc"> Â <delÂ xml:lang="grc">á¼ÏÎ»Î·ÏÏÎ¸Î· Ïá½¸ ÏÎ­ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿Î½</del> Â <addÂ place="above"Â xml:lang="grc">ÎÎ¯ÏÏÎ½Î¿Ï ÎÎ·ÏÎ±Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¬</add> </rubric>
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element del
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   att.dimensions.attributes,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   }?,
   text
}

Appendix A.1.25 <depth/>

<depth/> contains a measurement from the front to the back of an object, perpendicular to the measurement given by the <width/> element. [10.3.4. Dimensions]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributes
unitnames the unit used for the measurement
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
mm
quantityspecifies the length in the units specified
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
minwhere the measurement summarizes more than one observation or a range, supplies the minimum value observed.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
maxwhere the measurement summarizes more than one observation or a range, supplies the maximum value observed.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
Member of
model.measureLike
Contained by
core: q
msdescription: dimensions
May containEmpty element
Example
<dimensionsÂ type="binding"> Â <heightÂ quantity="240"Â unit="mm"/> Â <widthÂ quantity="185"Â unit="mm"/> Â <depthÂ quantity="65"Â unit="mm"/> </dimensions>
Schematronchecks that the <depth/> element has either a quantity or min/max attributes.
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:depth"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="@quantity or (@min and @max)">The depth element must have either @quantity or @min/@max. </sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element depth
{
   attribute unit { "mm" },
   attribute quantity { text }?,
   attribute min { text }?,
   attribute max { text }?,
   empty
}

Example
<facsimile> Â <surfaceÂ xml:id="uub-gr-021_1r"> Â Â <desc>f. 1r</desc> Â Â <graphicÂ url="uub-gr-021_0005_001r.tif"Â height="3864px"Â width="3486px"/> Â </surface> </facsimile>
SchematronA <desc> with a type of deprecationInfo should only occur when its parent element is being deprecated. Furthermore, it should always occur in an element that is being deprecated when <desc> is a valid child of that element.
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:desc[ @type eq 'deprecationInfo']"> <sch:assertÂ test="../@validUntil">Information about a deprecation should only be present in a specification element that is being deprecated: that is, only an element that has a @validUntil attribute should have a child <desc type="deprecationInfo">.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>

Appendix A.1.27 <dimensions>

<dimensions> contains a dimensional specification. [10.3.4. Dimensions]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
typeindicates which aspect of the object is being measured.

Datatypeteidata.enumerated

binding

chainLines
leaf
watermark

model.pPart.msdesc

Contains no more than one of each of the specialized elements used to express a three-dimensional object's height, width, and depth, combined with any number of other kinds of dimensional specification.

Example

Â </sequence>

   attribute type

      "binding" | "box" | "chainLines" | "leaf" | "watermark" | "written"
   },
   ( height?, width?, depth? )
}

Greek should be normalized: the first letter of each sentence and of names should be capitalized, iota subscripts should be added, and abbreviations expanded.

<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msPart/tei:physDesc/tei:objectDesc/tei:supportDesc/tei:extent"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="tei:measure[@type='textblockLeaves']"> Only the extent of the unit should be recorded here. The extent of the textblock should be recorded under respective msPart.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>

May contain

Example
<fileDesc> Â <titleStmt/> Â <publicationStmt/> Â <sourceDesc/> </fileDesc>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="titleStmt"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="publicationStmt"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="sourceDesc"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element fileDesc { titleStmt, publicationStmt, sourceDesc }

Appendix A.1.34 <filiation>

<filiation> contains information concerning the manuscript or other object's filiation, i.e. its relationship to other surviving manuscripts or other objects of the same text or contents, its protographs, antigraphs and apographs. [10.6.1. The msItem and msItemStruct Elements]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
typecharacterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
apograph
protograph
siglum
Contained by
msdescription: msItem
May contain
core: bibl listBibl note ref
header: idno
Example
<filiationÂ type="protograph"> Â <idnoÂ type="msRef">Codex Vaticanus Palatinus Graecus 267</idno> (15th cent.), cf. <bibl> Â Â <refÂ target="#DeStefani1902"/> Â Â <citedRangeÂ from="209"Â to="210"Â unit="page"/> Â </bibl> , <bibl> Â Â <refÂ target="#GarcÃ­aValdÃ©s2009"/> Â Â <citedRangeÂ from="viii"Â to="viii"Â unit="page"/> Â </bibl> </filiation> <filiationÂ type="siglum">U ( <bibl> Â Â <refÂ target="#DeStefani1902"/> Â </bibl>, <bibl> Â Â <refÂ target="#GarcÃ­aValdÃ©s2009"/> Â </bibl> )</filiation>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="ref"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â </alternate>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="bibl"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="listBibl"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â </alternate>
Â <elementRefÂ key="note"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element filiation
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute type { "apograph" | "protograph" | "siglum" }?,
   ( ref | idno ),
   ( bibl | listBibl ),
   note?
}

Appendix A.1.35 <finalRubric>

<finalRubric> contains the string of words that denotes the end of a text division, often with an assertion as to its author and title, usually set off from the text itself by red ink, by a different size or type of script, or by some other such visual device. [10.6.1. The msItem and msItemStruct Elements]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.msExcerpt (@defective) att.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453)) Greek should be normalized: the first letter of each sentence and of names should be capitalized, iota subscripts should be added, and abbreviations expanded.
la
(Latin)
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
Contained by
msdescription: msItem
May contain
core: foreign gap sic unclear
transcr: supplied
character data
Example
<finalRubricÂ xml:lang="grc">ÎÎ¯ÏÏÎ½Î¿Ï ÎºÎ±ÏÎ±ÏÎºÎµÏÎ±á½¶ ÏÎ¿Î»ÎµÎ¼Î¹Îºá¿¶Î½ á½ÏÎ³Î¬Î½ÏÎ½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±ÏÎ±ÏÎµÎ»ÏÎ¹Îºá¿¶Î½</finalRubric>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="foreign"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="gap"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="supplied"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="sic"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="unclear"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element finalRubric
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   att.msExcerpt.attributes,
   attribute xml:lang { "grc" | "la" | "non-swe" },
   ( text | foreign | gap | supplied | sic | unclear )*
}

Appendix A.1.37 <foreign>

<foreign> identifies a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than that of the surrounding text. [3.3.2.1. Foreign Words or Expressions]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: note p q quote title
header: handNote
msdescription: acquisition colophon decoNote explicit finalRubric foliation incipit origin provenance
May contain
core: lb unclear
transcr: ex
character data
Note

The global xml:lang attribute should be supplied for this element to identify the language of the word or phrase marked. As elsewhere, its value should be a language tag as defined in 6.1. Language Identification.

This element is intended for use only where no other element is available to mark the phrase or words concerned. The global xml:lang attribute should be used in preference to this element where it is intended to mark the language of the whole of some text element.

The <distinct> element may be used to identify phrases belonging to sublanguages or registers not generally regarded as true languages.

Example
The total amount paid for the two volumes was 84 <foreignÂ xml:lang="sv">Daler kopparmynt</foreign>.
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="ex"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="lb"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="unclear"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element foreign
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   },
   ( text | ex* | lb* | unclear* )*
}

Appendix A.1.39 <funder>

<funder> (funding body) specifies the name of an individual, institution, or organization responsible for the funding of a project or text. [2.2.1. The Title Statement]
Moduleheader â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.canonical (key, @ref)
Contained by
header: titleStmt
May containCharacter data only
Note

Funders provide financial support for a project; they are distinct from sponsors (see element <sponsor>), who provide intellectual support and authority.

Example
<funder>The National Endowment for the Humanities, an independent federal agency</funder> <funder>Directorate General XIII of the Commission of the European Communities</funder> <funder>The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation</funder> <funder>The Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada</funder>
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element funder { att.canonical.attribute.ref, text }

Appendix A.1.40 <gap/>

<gap/> indicates a point where material has been omitted in a transcription, whether for editorial reasons described in the TEI header, as part of sampling practice, or because the material is illegible, invisible, or inaudible. [3.4.3. Additions, Deletions, and Omissions]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
unitnames the unit used for the measurement
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
chars
characters
lines
mm
quantityspecifies the length in the units specified
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.numeric
atLeastgives a minimum estimated value for the approximate measurement.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
atMostgives a maximum estimated value for the approximate measurement.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
reasongives the reason for omission
StatusRequired
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
damage
Physical damage in the manuscript
lacuna
Gap left by the scribe in the manuscript
Member of
model.global.edit
Contained by
core: q
msdescription: colophon explicit finalRubric incipit
May containEmpty element
Example
<gapÂ reason="damage"Â quantity="20"Â unit="mm"/> <unclearÂ reason="illegible"Â quantity="60"Â unit="mm"/> á¼°Î¿ÏÎ´Î¬Î½Î·Ï á¼°Î¿ÏÎ´Î¬Î½Î·Ï á¼°Î¿ÏÎ´Î¬Î½Î¿Ï ÏÎµÎ»<unclearÂ reason="illegible"Â quantity="30"Â unit="mm"/> Î±á¼°Î´Î­ÏÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï, á¼Î¾Î¹Î¿ÏÎ¯Î¼Î·ÏÎ¿Ï
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element gap
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute unit { "chars" | "lines" | "mm" },
   attribute quantity { text },
   attribute atLeast { text }?,
   attribute atMost { text }?,
   attribute reason { list { ( "damage" | "lacuna" )+ } },
   empty
}

      ( locus | locusGrp )?,

         text
       |Â bibl
       |Â date
       |Â foreign
       |Â idno

   )

Appendix A.1.45 <height/>

<height/> contains a measurement measured along the axis at a right angle to the bottom of the object. [10.3.4. Dimensions]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributes
unitnames the unit used for the measurement
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
mm
quantityspecifies the length in the units specified
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
minwhere the measurement summarizes more than one observation or a range, supplies the minimum value observed.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
maxwhere the measurement summarizes more than one observation or a range, supplies the maximum value observed.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
Member of
model.measureLike
Contained by
core: q
msdescription: dimensions
May containEmpty element
Example
<dimensionsÂ type="binding"> Â <heightÂ quantity="240"Â unit="mm"/> Â <widthÂ quantity="185"Â unit="mm"/> Â <depthÂ quantity="65"Â unit="mm"/> </dimensions>
Schematronchecks that the <height/> element has either a quantity or min/max attributes.
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:height"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="@quantity or (@min and @max)">The height element must have either @quantity or @min/@max. </sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element height
{
   attribute unit { "mm" },
   attribute quantity { text }?,
   attribute min { text }?,
   attribute max { text }?,
   empty
}

<history> Â <origin>Probably written in <origPlaceÂ ref="#Venice"/> in the <origDateÂ notBefore="1535"Â notAfter="1555">1540s</origDate>. Watermarks and the handwriting (in so-called <qÂ xml:lang="de">Camillus-Schrift</q> style) may suggest a link to the workshop of <persNameÂ ref="#BarZan"/>. Its present binding stems from the <dateÂ notBefore="1746"Â notAfter="1765">mid-eighteenth century</date>.</origin> Â <provenance>The manuscript was acquired by <persNameÂ ref="#JacBjÃ¶"/> (<dateÂ from="1731"Â to="1779"/>), most probably during his travels through Europe in the years <dateÂ from="1767"Â to="1779"/>. That it would, as is the case with several of his other manuscripts, have its provenance in one of the Thessalian monasteries, is perhaps less likely given its rather costly binding in silk and brocatpapier. </provenance> Â <acquisition>Came to <placeNameÂ ref="#UUL"/> in <dateÂ when="1784"/> as part of the BjÃ¶rnstÃ¥hl donation. </acquisition> </history>

   ( origin?, provenance*, acquisition? )

}

Appendix A.1.49 <incipit>

<incipit> contains the incipit of a manuscript or similar object item, that is the opening words of the text proper, exclusive of any rubric which might precede it, of sufficient length to identify the work uniquely; such incipits were, in former times, frequently used a means of reference to a work, in place of a title. [10.6.1. The msItem and msItemStruct Elements]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453)) Greek should be normalized: the first letter of each sentence and of names should be capitalized, iota subscripts should be added, and abbreviations expanded.
la
(Latin)
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
defectiveindicates whether the passage being quoted is defective, i.e. incomplete through loss or damage.
Derived fromatt.msExcerpt
StatusRecommended
Datatypeteidata.xTruthValue
Contained by
msdescription: msItem
May contain
core: foreign gap sic unclear
transcr: supplied
character data
Example
<incipitÂ xml:lang="grc"Â defective="false">Î á¾¶Î½ ÏÏá¾¶Î³Î¼Î± á¼¢ Î´Î¹Î±Î¹ÏÎµÏá½¸Î½ á¼¢ á¼Î´Î¹Î±Î¯ÏÎµÏÎ¿Î½</incipit>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="foreign"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="gap"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="supplied"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="sic"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="unclear"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element incipit
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute xml:lang { "grc" | "la" | "non-swe" },
   attribute defective { text }?,
   ( text | foreign | gap | supplied | sic | unclear )*
}

Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributes
ref(reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Derived fromatt.canonical
StatusRequired
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace

May containCharacter data only
Example
<msIdentifier> Â <countryÂ ref="#Sweden"/> Â <settlementÂ ref="#Uppsala"/> Â <institutionÂ ref="#UU"/> Â <repositoryÂ ref="#UUB"/> Â <idnoÂ type="shelfmark">Gr. 27</idno> </msIdentifier>

Appendix A.1.52 <layout>

<layout> describes how text is laid out on the page or surface of the object, including information about any ruling, pricking, or other evidence of page-preparation techniques. [10.7.2. Writing, Decoration, and Other Notations]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
columnsspecifies the number of columns per page
StatusOptional
Datatype1â2 occurrences ofÂ teidata.count separated by whitespace
Note

If a single number is given, all pages referenced have this number of columns. If two numbers are given, the number of columns per page varies between the values supplied. Where columns is omitted the number is assumed to be 1.

Columns may be independent of page orientation or reading direction, and a single textual stream may have one or more columns.

ruledLinesspecifies the number of ruled lines per column
StatusOptional
Datatype1â2 occurrences ofÂ teidata.count separated by whitespace
Note

If a single number is given, all columns have this number of ruled lines. If two numbers are given, the number of ruled lines per column varies between the values supplied.

writtenLinesspecifies the number of written lines per column
StatusOptional
Datatype1â2 occurrences ofÂ teidata.count separated by whitespace
Note

If a single number is given, all columns have this number of written lines. If two numbers are given, the number of written lines per column varies between the values supplied.

Contained by
msdescription: layoutDesc
May contain
core: bibl note term
msdescription: dimensions locus locusGrp
Example
<layoutDesc> Â <layoutÂ columns="1"Â ruledLines="20"Â writtenLines="38 39"> Â Â <locusÂ from="1r"Â to="91v"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â <termÂ type="layout">ruling pattern</term> Â Â <termÂ type="proximity">identical with</term> Â Â <bibl> Â Â Â <refÂ target="#Sautel1995"/> Â Â Â <citedRangeÂ unit="number"Â from="20D1"Â to="20D1"/> Â Â </bibl> Â Â <dimensionsÂ type="written"> Â Â Â <heightÂ min="185"Â max="190"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â Â <widthÂ min="125"Â max="130"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â </dimensions> Â </layout> </layoutDesc>
SchematronCheck that the <term> element with the type attribute proximity containts the permitted values "similar to", "very similar to", "identical with", or "not clear".
<sch:ruleÂ context="//tei:layout/tei:term[@type='proximity']"> <sch:assertÂ test="text()='similar to' or text()='very similar to' or text()='identical with' or text()='not clear'"> Permitted values are "similar to", "very similar to", "identical with", or "not clear".</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="locus"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="locusGrp"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="term"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="bibl"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="dimensions"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="note"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element layout
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute columns { list { ? } }?,
   attribute ruledLines { list { ? } }?,
   attribute writtenLines { list { ? } }?,
   ( ( locus | locusGrp ), term*, bibl?, dimensions?, note? )
}

Appendix A.1.59 <locus/>

<locus/> defines a location within a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object typically as a (possibly discontinuous) sequence of folio references. [10.3.5. References to Locations within a Manuscript]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.typed (@type, @subtype)
schemeidentifies the foliation scheme in terms of which the location is being specified by pointing to some <foliation> element defining it, or to some other equivalent resource.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.pointer
Legal values are:
folios
pages
other
Use for spine and covers
fromspecifies the starting point of the location in a normalized form, typically a page number.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.word
tospecifies the end-point of the location in a normalized form, typically as a page number.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.word
Member of
model.pPart.msdesc
Contained by
core: item note p q
header: handNote
msdescription: acquisition catchwords colophon condition decoNote foliation layout locusGrp msItem origin provenance signatures
May containEmpty element
Note

The target attribute should only be used to point to elements that contain or indicate a transcription of the locus being described, as in the first example above. To associate a <locus/> element with a page image or other comparable representation, the global facs attribute should be used instead, as shown in the second example. Use of the target attribute to indicate an image is strongly deprecated. The facs attribute may be used to indicate one or more image files, as above, or alternatively it may point to one or more appropriate XML elements, such as the <surface>, <zone> element, <graphic/>, or <binaryObject> elements.

Note

When a single page is being cited, use the from and to attributes with an identical value. When no clear endpoint is provided, the from attribute may be used without to; for example a citation such as âp. 3ffâ might be encoded <biblScope from="3">p. 3ff<biblScope>.

Example
<locusÂ from="1r"Â to="119r"Â scheme="folios"/>
SchematronCheck if <locus/> is used more than once when not inside a <locusGrp>
<sch:ruleÂ context="//tei:locusGrp"> <sch:reportÂ test="count(tei:locus) < 2"> Only use locusGrp when grouping together more than one locus.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
SchematronCheck for prohibited values in the from and to attributes
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:locus"> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[starts-with(., 'i') or starts-with(., 'v') or starts-with(., 'x')] or @to[starts-with(., 'i') or starts-with(., 'v') or starts-with(., 'x')]"> The use of roman numerals is not allowed. Use L1r or L1v for left endleaves and R1r or R1v for right endleaves.</sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[matches(., 'lco')] or @to[matches(., 'lco')]"> Use LCO for left cover outside.</sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[matches(., 'lci')] or @to[matches(., 'lci')]"> Use LCI for left cover inside.</sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[matches(., 'rci')] or @to[matches(., 'rci')]"> Use RCI for right cover inside.</sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[matches(., 'rco')] or @to[matches(., 'rco')]"> Use RCO for right cover outside.</sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[matches(., 'Spine')] or @to[matches(., 'Spine')]"> Use spine with lower-case.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
SchematronCheck that the scheme attribute has the value folios when referring to folios.
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:locus[@scheme='pages' or @scheme='other']"> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[contains(., 'r') or contains(., 'v')]"> Use the scheme attribute with the value folios when referring to folios.</sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="@to[contains(., 'r') or contains(., 'v')]"> Use the scheme attribute with the value folios when referring to folios.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
SchematronCheck that the scheme attribute has the value other when referring to the spine och covers.
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:locus[@scheme='folios' or @scheme='pages']"> <sch:reportÂ test="@from[matches(., 'spine')] or @from[matches(., 'LCO')] or @from[matches(., 'LCI')] or @to[matches(., 'spine')] or @to[matches(., 'RCO')] or @to[matches(., 'RCI')]"> Use the scheme attribute with the value other when referring to the spine or covers.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element locus
{
   att.typed.attributes,
   attribute scheme { "folios" | "pages" | "other" },
   attribute from { text },
   attribute to { text },
   empty
}

Appendix A.1.62 <measure>

<measure> contains a word or phrase referring to some quantity of an object or commodity, usually comprising a number, a unit, and a commodity name. [3.5.3. Numbers and Measures]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.measurement (unit, quantity, @unitRef)

Legal values are:

folios
quantityspecifies the number of the specified units that comprise the measurement

StatusRecommended

Content model

Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element measure
{
   att.measurement.attribute.unitRef,
   attribute unit { "mm" | "lines" | "folios" }?,
   attribute quantity { text }?,
   attribute type
   {
      "leftFlyleaves"
    |Â "rightFlyleaves"
    |Â "textblockLeaves"
    |Â "laidLinesIn20mm"
    |Â "folding"
   },
   text
}

Appendix A.1.63 <msContents>

<msContents> (manuscript contents) describes the intellectual content of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object either as a series of paragraphs or as a series of structured manuscript items. [10.6. Intellectual Content]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
Contained by
msdescription: msDesc msFrag msPart
May contain
core: textLang
msdescription: msItem summary
Note

Unless it contains a simple prose description, this element should contain at least one of the elements <summary>, <msItem>, or <msItemStruct>. This constraint is not currently enforced by the schema.

Example
<msContents> Â <textLangÂ mainLang="grc"/> Â <msItemÂ class="schol"> Â Â <locusÂ from="27v:12"Â to="27v:31"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â <author> Â Â Â <persNameÂ ref="#ManHol"/> Â Â </author> Â Â <titleÂ ref="http://pinakes.irht.cnrs.fr/notices/oeuvre/id/1420"Â type="uniform"Â xml:lang="la">Commentarius in securim</title> Â Â <rubricÂ xml:lang="grc">Î¤Î¿á¿¦ á½Î»Î¿Î²ÏÎ»Î¿Ï Îµá¼°Ï Ïá½¸Î½ Î Î­Î»ÎµÎºÏÎ½ á¼Î¾Î®Î³Î·ÏÎ¹Ï ÏÏÎ½Î¿ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÎ®</rubric> Â Â <incipitÂ xml:lang="grc"Â defective="false">á½ ÏÎ­Î»ÎµÎºÏÏ Î¿á½Ï <suppliedÂ reason="omitted"Â xml:lang="grc">á½¡Ï</supplied> á½ Î£ÏÏÎ¹Î³Î¾ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¿á¼± ÎÏÎ¼Î¿á½¶</incipit> Â Â <explicitÂ xml:lang="grc"Â defective="false">á½Î»Î²Î¹Î¿Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá½ÏÏÏá½´Ï á¼Îµá½¶ ÏÎ½Îµá¿ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¶á¿</explicit> Â </msItem> </msContents>

</content>

Appendix A.1.64 <msDesc>

<msDesc> (manuscript description) contains a description of a single identifiable manuscript or other text-bearing object. [10.1. Overview]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
resp(responsible party) indicates the agency responsible for the intervention or interpretation, for example an editor or transcriber.
Derived fromatt.global.responsibility
StatusRequired
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
model.biblLike
Contained by
core: q
header: sourceDesc
May contain
core: head
msdescription: additional history msContents msFrag msIdentifier msPart physDesc
Example
<msDesc> Â <msIdentifier> Â Â <countryÂ ref="https://www.manuscripta.se/place/100081">Sweden</country> Â Â <settlementÂ ref="https://www.manuscripta.se/place/100089">Uppsala</settlement> Â Â <institutionÂ ref="https://www.manuscripta.se/place/100091">Uppsala University</institution> Â Â <repositoryÂ ref="https://www.manuscripta.se/place/100092">Uppsala University Library</repository> Â Â <idnoÂ type="shelfmark">Gr. 27</idno> Â </msIdentifier> Â <head>Aelian, On Animals</head> <!-- MS description --> </msDesc>
SchematronChecks that folio and page references are only given in <locus/> elements and not in the running text.
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msDesc//*"> Â <sch:reportÂ test="text()[matches(., ' f. \p{N}| ff. \p{N}')]"> Do not use f./ff. in the running text for folio references. Use the locus element instead.</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="text()[matches(., ' p. \p{N}| pp. \p{N}')]"> Do not use p./pp. in the running text for page references. Use the locus element instead.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="msIdentifier"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="model.headLike"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="msContents"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="physDesc"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="history"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="additional"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="msPart"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="msFrag"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element msDesc
{
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   },
   attribute resp { list { + } },
   msIdentifier,
   model.headLike,
   msContents?,
   physDesc?,
   history?,
   additional?,
   ( msPart+ | msFrag+ )
}

Appendix A.1.65 <msFrag>

<msFrag> (manuscript fragment) contains information about a fragment described in relation to a prior context, typically as a description of a virtual reconstruction of a manuscript or other object whose fragments were catalogued separately [10.11. Manuscript Fragments]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.typed (@type, @subtype)
Contained by
msdescription: msDesc
May contain
msdescription: history msContents msIdentifier physDesc
Example
<msDesc> Â <msIdentifier> Â Â <msNameÂ xml:lang="la">Codex Suprasliensis</msName> Â </msIdentifier> Â <msFrag> Â Â <msIdentifier> Â Â Â <settlement>Ljubljana</settlement> Â Â Â <repository>Narodna in univerzitetna knjiznica</repository> Â Â Â <idno>MS Kopitar 2</idno> Â Â </msIdentifier> Â Â <msContents> Â Â Â <summary>Contains ff. 10 to 42 only</summary> Â Â </msContents> Â </msFrag> Â <msFrag> Â Â <msIdentifier> Â Â Â <settlement>Warszawa</settlement> Â Â Â <repository>Biblioteka Narodowa</repository> Â Â Â <idno>BO 3.201</idno> Â Â </msIdentifier> Â </msFrag> Â <msFrag> Â Â <msIdentifier> Â Â Â <settlement>Sankt-Peterburg</settlement> Â Â Â <repository>Rossiiskaia natsional'naia biblioteka</repository> Â Â Â <idno>Q.p.I.72</idno> Â Â </msIdentifier> Â </msFrag> </msDesc>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="msIdentifier"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="msContents"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="physDesc"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="history"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element msFrag
{
   att.typed.attributes,
   msIdentifier,
   msContents,
   physDesc,
   history?
}

Appendix A.1.66 <msIdentifier>

<msIdentifier> (manuscript identifier) contains the information required to identify the manuscript or similar object being described. [10.4. The Manuscript Identifier]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
Contained by
msdescription: msDesc msFrag msPart
May contain
header: idno
msdescription: altIdentifier collection institution msName repository
namesdates: country settlement
Example
<msIdentifier> Â <country>Sweden</country> Â <settlement>Uppsala</settlement> Â <institution>Uppsala University</institution> Â <repository>Uppsala University Library</repository> Â <idnoÂ type="shelfmark">Gr. 28A</idno> Â <msName>Codex Rolambianus</msName> Â <altIdentifier> Â Â <idnoÂ type="formerShelfmark">Benzelius 2</idno> Â </altIdentifier> </msIdentifier>
Schematron
<s:reportÂ test="not(parent::tei:msPart) and (local-name(*[1])='idno' or local-name(*[1])='altIdentifier' or normalize-space(.)='')">An msIdentifier must contain either a repository or location.</s:report>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="country"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="settlement"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="institution"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="repository"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="collection"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â </sequence>
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="msName"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="altIdentifier"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element msIdentifier
{
   ( country?, settlement?, institution?, repository?, collection?, idno ),
   ( msName | altIdentifier )*
}

Appendix A.1.67 <msItem>

<msItem> (manuscript item) describes an individual work or item within the intellectual content of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object. [10.6.1. The msItem and msItemStruct Elements]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributes
defectiveindicates whether the passage being quoted is defective, i.e. incomplete through loss or damage.
Derived fromatt.msExcerpt
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.xTruthValue
classidentifies the text types or classifications applicable to this item by pointing to other elements or resources defining the classification concerned.
Derived fromatt.msClass
StatusRecommended
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
leftEndleaf
(Left endleaf)
rightEndleaf
(Right endleaf)
acta
(Acta)
alchem
(Alchemica)
anthol
(Anthologia) is used to classify postclassical collections such as the Anthologia Graeca that represent a sizeable collection constructed in late antiquity from earlier disparate sources. (http://www.tlg.uci.edu/help/class.html)
apocalyp
(Apocalypsis) defines works of a prophetic nature but with a focus clearly directed "towards the end of things and to the destiny of the world in general." (F.L. Cross, The Oxford dictionary of the Christian church [London 1958] 67). Prophecies that look toward the future but without the apocalyptic vision of a grand terminus are labeled Prophet.
apocryph
(Apocrypha) is used to identify two kinds of works: 1) works that have come down to us as part of the Septuagint but were not part of the traditional Hebrew Bible and 2) works that are generally regarded by Christians as extracanonical in relation to the New Testament. Pseudepigr. on the other hand, has been used for works that belong neither to the Septuagint not to the Hebrew Bible but have been transmitted under the name of a Jewish religious thinker.
astrolog
(Astrologica)
apol
(Apologetica) is applied to works written in defense of the tenets of one religious system against those of another. It is also used of works written in justification of orthodox Christian faith in opposition to heretical beliefs.
biogr
(Biographa) indicates both biographical and autobiographical writings.
bucol
(Bucolica)
caten
(Catena) is restricted to scholiastic comment upon biblical passages and lists of variae lectiones to a given catena on a biblical passage. Commentaries by individual authors ot scriptural texts are classified as Exeget. whereas commenta derived from catenae are tagged both as Exeget. and Caten.
chronogr
(Chronographa)
comic
(Comica)
comm
(Commentarius)
concil
(Concilia) signifies a miscellany of writings including speeches, letters, rosters, and proceedings of ecumenical councils.
dialog
(Dialogus) is reserved for literary works written in the form of a prose dialogue.
doxogr
(Doxographa)
eccl
(Ecclesiastica) is a multipurpose tag attached to works that seem to be ecclesiastical in nature but lack characteristics that would permit a more specific definition. In general, Eccl. refers to themes, concerns, and attitudes associated with the Christian church.
epic
(Epica)
epigr
(Epigrammatica)
epist
(Epistolographa)
evang
(Evangelica)
encom
(Encomiastica) is used for eulogy, panegyric, laudationes or any kind of work (poetry or prose) that falls under the general variety of laudatory literature.
exeget
(Exegetica) distinguishes writings that interpret the texts of the Old and New Testaments from the commentaries that focus upon secular literature.
fab
(Fabula)
geogr
(Geographa)
gnom
(Gnomica)
gramm
(Grammatica) is used to tag those works explicitly entitled Ars grammatica or Fragmenta grammatica, as well as treatises on prosody, orthography, accentuation, parts of speech, and inflection.
hagiogr
(Hagiographica) is used to characterize works whose principal themes are the lives and acts of saints, martyrs, and heroic figures in Judaeo-Christian tradition.
hexametr
(Hexametrica) is used of poems (or fragments of poems) that do not betray a generic affiliation with some species of poetry in terms of theme or tone. The generic tags Epic., Bucol., and Parod., when used, indicate an implicit assumption of the hexameter form. In these cases, the tag Hexametr. is not added.
hist
(Historica) is added to the following categories: extant works of Greek historians; fragments of lost historical works collected in independent editions or generic collections such as FGrH, FHG, and HGM, and works of ecclesiastical writers that focus upon the history of the Church.
homilet
(Homiletica) is used to distinguish homiliae (i.e. discourses on religious and moral topics delivered, or written as though they were intended for delivery to a congregation) from orationes (i.e. discourses on secular topics).
hymn
(Hymnus) is assigned, regardless of meter, to the great variety of hymnal poetry ranging from the Hymni Homerici to the polymetric hymns of Gregory of Nazianzus.
hypoth
(Hypothesis) defines the hypotheses transmitted as prefixes to Greek tragedies and comedies.
iamb
(Iambica)
invectiv
(Invectiva)
jurisprud
(Jurisprudentia)
legal
(Legalia)
lexicogr
(Lexicographa) is used for word-lists and glossaries but also any lexicon that incorporates commentary.
liturg
(Liturgica)
lyr
(Lyrica)
magica
(Magica)
math
(Mathematica)
mech
(Mechanica)
med
(Medica) is applied to a wide range of medical writings (including veterinary treatises and writings that deal with antidotes and pharmacological prescriptions.
metrolog
(Metrologica)
mim
(Mimus)
mus
(Musica) is used to classify theoretical works on music but also musical scales, notations and fragments of music.
myth
(Mythographa) is used to classify the works of mythographers but also works of historians (especially the early logographers) who cited myths as evidence in their historical accounts.
narrFict
(Narratio Ficta) is used to categorize a variety of novelistic writings that range from novel or romance to novella, story, tale, and vignette.
natHist
(Naturalis Historia) includes a broad range of topics such as animal nature, horse breeding and training, colors, stones, rivers, meteorology, and agriculture.
onir
(Onirocritica)
orac
(Oraculum)
orat
(Oratio)
paradox
(Paradoxographa)
parod
(Parodica)
paroem
(Paroemiographica)
perieg
(Periegesis)
phil
(Philosophica)
physiognom
(Physiognomica)
pinax
(Pinax)
poem
(Poema) indicates metrical pieces that do not readily admit generic definition either by reason of meter or in terms of themes and tone.
polyhist
(Polyhistorica)
prophet
(Prophetia)
pseudepigr
(Pseudepigrapha)
relig
(Religiosa) is used exclusively to designate texts that constitute the basis for the scripturae sacrae of Judaeo-Christian tradition. The term has been used only for the 27 books ofr the New Testament and the 59 works of the Septuaginta.
rhet
(Rhetorica) is used to classify works concerned with the art, science, theories, and techniques of persuasion, of which oratory is the principal beneficiary.
satura
(Satura)
satyr
(Satyra)
schol
(Scholia)
tact
(Tactica)
test
(Testimonia)
theol
(Theologica) is used to classify works that can be defined as religious literature insofar as they are concerned primarily with the nature of divinity, the relationship between human and divine, religious doctrine, and other spiritual matters. A distinction is made between Theol. and Eccl. where Eccl. characterizes matters of interest to the Christian church but without principal focus upon divinity.
trag
(Tragica)
zool
(Zoologica)
Contained by
msdescription: msContents msItem
May contain
core: author bibl listBibl note quote textLang title
msdescription: colophon explicit filiation finalRubric incipit locus locusGrp msItem rubric
Example
<msItemÂ class="phil"> Â <locusÂ from="26r"Â to="26r"Â scheme="folios"/> Â <titleÂ type="desc"Â xml:lang="en">A diagram on logical categories</title> Â <incipitÂ xml:lang="grc"Â defective="false">Î á¾¶Î½ ÏÏá¾¶Î³Î¼Î± á¼¢ Î´Î¹Î±Î¹ÏÎµÏá½¸Î½ á¼¢ á¼Î´Î¹Î±Î¯ÏÎµÏÎ¿Î½</incipit> Â <explicitÂ xml:lang="grc"Â defective="false">á½¡Ï Ïá¿¶Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±Î¯Î½ÏÎ½, Ïá½° Î¼á½²Î½ ÏÏÏÏÎ¬, Ïá½° Î´á½² ÏÎµÏÎ¼Î¬</explicit> </msItem>
Schematronchecks that the <msItem> element contains at least a <locus/> or <locusGrp> and a <note>.
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msItem"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:note or (tei:textLang or tei:author or tei:title or tei:rubric or tei:msItem or tei:incipit or tei:quote or tei:explicit or tei:finalRubric or tei:colophon or tei:filiation or tei:listBibl or tei:bibl)"> The msItem element must contain at least a locus or locusGrp and a note element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="locus"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="locusGrp"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="textLang"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="author"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="title"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="rubric"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="msItem"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="incipit"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="quote"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="explicit"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="finalRubric"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="note"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="colophon"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="filiation"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="listBibl"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="bibl"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â Â </alternate>
Â Â Â </sequence>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="note"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element msItem
{
   attribute defective { text }?,
   attribute class
   {
      list
      {
         (
            "leftEndleaf"
          |Â "rightEndleaf"
          |Â "acta"
          |Â "alchem"
          |Â "anthol"

          |Â "caten"

          |Â "comic"
          |Â "comm"
          |Â "concil"
          |Â "dialog"
          |Â "doxogr"
          |Â "eccl"
          |Â "epic"
          |Â "epigr"
          |Â "epist"
          |Â "evang"
          |Â "encom"
          |Â "exeget"
          |Â "fab"
          |Â "geogr"
          |Â "gnom"
          |Â "gramm"

          |Â "hexametr"

          |Â "mech"
          |Â "med"
          |Â "metrolog"
          |Â "mim"
          |Â "mus"
          |Â "myth"
          |Â "narrFict"
          |Â "natHist"
          |Â "onir"
          |Â "orac"
          |Â "orat"
          |Â "paradox"

          |Â "paroem"
          |Â "perieg"
          |Â "phil"

          |Â "pinax"
          |Â "poem"

          |Â "theol"

         )+
      }
   }?,
   (
      ( locus | locusGrp ),
      (
         (
            textLang?,
            author*,
            title+,
            rubric?,
            msItem*,
            incipit?,
            quote?,
            explicit?,
            finalRubric?,
            note?,
            colophon?,

         )
       |Â note
      )
   )
}

Appendix A.1.68 <msName>

<msName> (alternative name) contains any form of unstructured alternative name used for a manuscript or other object, such as an âocellus nominumâ, or nickname. [10.4. The Manuscript Identifier]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
Contained by
msdescription: msIdentifier
May containCharacter data only
Example
<msNameÂ xml:lang="la">Codex Rolambianus</msName>
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element msName
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   }?,
   text
}

Appendix A.1.69 <msPart>

<msPart> (manuscript part) contains information about an originally distinct manuscript or part of a manuscript, which is now part of a composite manuscript. [10.10. Manuscript Parts]
Modulemsdescription â Schema

Â <elementRefÂ key="physDesc"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="history"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
</content>

Appendix A.1.70 <musicNotation>

<musicNotation> contains description of type of musical notation. [10.7.2. Writing, Decoration, and Other Notations]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
Contained by
msdescription: physDesc
May contain
core: term
character data
Example
<musicNotation> Â <p>Square notation of 4-line red staves.</p> </musicNotation>
Example
<musicNotation>Neumes in <term>campo aperto</term> of the St. Gall type. </musicNotation>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="term"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element musicNotation { ( text | term )* }

Appendix A.1.71 <note>

<note> contains a note or annotation. [3.8.1. Notes and Simple Annotation 2.2.6. The Notes Statement 3.11.2.8. Notes and Statement of Language 9.3.5.4. Notes within Entries]

Example
<note>With interlinear glosses and a few longer scholia. Following the main text, there are on <locusÂ from="24v"Â to="25v"Â scheme="folios"/> also sketches and diagrams relating to it (illustrating e.g. the four elements, agricultural implements, celestial bodies, the zodiac). The sketches may be compared to the illustrations in the Venice print edition from 1537: <bibl> Â Â <refÂ target="#Trincavelli1537"/> Â Â <citedRangeÂ unit="folio"Â from="CXIIv"Â to="CXIIv"/> Â </bibl>.</note>

Appendix A.1.72 <num>

<num> (number) contains a number, written in any form. [3.5.3. Numbers and Measures]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
typeindicates the type of numeric value.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
cardinal
absolute number, e.g. 21, 21.5
ordinal
ordinal number, e.g. 21st
Note

If a different typology is desired, other values can be used for this attribute.

valuesupplies the value of the number in standard form.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.numeric
Valuesa numeric value.
Note

The standard form used is defined by the TEI datatype data.numeric.

Member of
model.measureLike
Contained by
core: q
msdescription: colophon foliation signatures
May contain
core: hi
character data
Note

Detailed analyses of quantities and units of measure in historical documents may also use the feature structure mechanism described in chapter 18. Feature Structures. The <num> element is intended for use in simple applications.

Example
<numÂ xml:lang="grc"Â type="cardinal"Â value="1">Î±Í´</num> <numÂ xml:lang="grc"Â type="cardinal"Â value="1000">ÍµÎ±</num> <numÂ xml:lang="grc"Â type="ordinal"Â value="4">Î´<hiÂ rend="sup">Î¿Ï</hi> </num>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="hi"/>
Â Â <textNode/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element num
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   },
   attribute type { "cardinal" | "ordinal" },
   attribute value { text },
   ( hi | text )*
}

Appendix A.1.73 <objectDesc>

<objectDesc> contains a description of the physical components making up the object which is being described. [10.7.1. Object Description]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributes
forma short project-specific name identifying the physical form of the carrier, for example as a codex, roll, fragment, partial leaf, cutting etc.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
codex
fragment
roll
Note

Definitions for the terms used may typically be provided by a <valList> element in the project schema specification.

Contained by
msdescription: physDesc
May contain
msdescription: layoutDesc supportDesc
Example
<objectDesc> Â <supportDescÂ material="parchment"> Â Â <support> Â Â Â <p> Â Â Â Â <locusÂ from="92r"Â to="220v"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â Â Â <dimensionsÂ type="leaf"> Â Â Â Â Â <heightÂ quantity="225"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â Â Â Â <widthÂ quantity="170"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â Â Â </dimensions> Â Â Â </p> Â Â </support> Â Â <extent> Â Â Â <measureÂ type="textblockLeaves"Â quantity="129"/> Â Â </extent> Â Â <collation> Â Â Â <formula> Â Â Â Â <hiÂ rend="sub">Q17â29</hi>13.IV<hiÂ rend="super">f.195</hi> + <hiÂ rend="sub">Q30</hi>(IV + 3f.<hiÂ rend="super">f.196â198</hi>)<hiÂ rend="super">f.206</hi>: 3 single leaves pasted together and onto the following quaternion + <hiÂ rend="sub">Q31</hi>IV<hiÂ rend="super">f.214</hi> + <hiÂ rend="sub">Q32</hi>III<hiÂ rend="super">f.220</hi> Â Â Â </formula> Â Â Â <signatures> Â Â Â Â <term>none</term> Â Â Â </signatures> Â Â Â <catchwords> Â Â Â Â <term>none</term> Â Â Â </catchwords> Â Â </collation> Â </supportDesc> Â <layoutDesc> Â Â <layoutÂ columns="1"Â ruledLines="21"Â writtenLines="39 41"> Â Â Â <locusÂ from="92r"Â to="220v"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â Â <termÂ type="layout">ruling pattern</term> Â Â Â <termÂ type="proximity">identical with</term> Â Â Â <bibl> Â Â Â Â <refÂ target="#Sautel1995"/> Â Â Â Â <citedRangeÂ unit="number"Â from="20D1"Â to="20D1"/> Â Â Â </bibl> Â Â Â <note>On some pages the <termÂ type="layout">ruling pattern</term> is closer to <bibl> Â Â Â Â Â <refÂ target="#Sautel1995"/> Â Â Â Â Â <citedRangeÂ unit="number"Â from="20A1"Â to="20A1"/> Â Â Â Â </bibl>, although this may be due to the scribe being less accurate in the execution.</note> Â Â Â <dimensionsÂ type="written"> Â Â Â Â <heightÂ min="195"Â max="200"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â Â Â <widthÂ min="130"Â max="135"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â Â </dimensions> Â Â </layout> Â </layoutDesc> </objectDesc>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msDesc/tei:physDesc/tei:objectDesc"> <sch:assertÂ test="@form"> The form attribute is mandatory </sch:assert> </sch:rule> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msDesc/tei:msPart/tei:physDesc/tei:objectDesc"> <sch:reportÂ test="@form"> The form attribute should not be used in msPart </sch:report> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="supportDesc"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>

Â </sequence>

   attribute form { "codex" | "fragment" | "roll" }?,
   ( supportDesc, layoutDesc? )
}

Appendix A.1.80 <persName>

<persName> (personal name) contains a proper noun or proper-noun phrase referring to a person, possibly including one or more of the person's forenames, surnames, honorifics, added names, etc. [13.2.1. Personal Names]
Modulenamesdates â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
cert(certainty) signifies the degree of certainty associated with the intervention or interpretation.
Derived fromatt.global.responsibility
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.probCert
evidenceindicates the nature of the evidence supporting the reliability or accuracy of the intervention or interpretation.
Derived fromatt.editLike
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
internal
there is internal evidence to support the intervention.
external
there is external evidence to support the intervention.
conjecture
the intervention or interpretation has been made by the editor, cataloguer, or scholar on the basis of their expertise.
rolemay be used to specify further information about the entity referenced by this name in the form of a set of whitespace-separated values, for example the occupation of a person, or the status of a place.
Derived fromatt.naming
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
cataloguer
librarian
scribe
ref(reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Derived fromatt.canonical
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
model.nameLike.agent
Contained by
core: author note p q ref respStmt title
header: handNote
msdescription: acquisition decoNote foliation origin provenance
May containCharacter data only
Example
<persNameÂ ref="#PehAur"Â role="librarian"Â evidence="conjecture"Â cert="medium"/>
SchematronCheck that cert is used when evidence is external or conjecture.
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:persName[@evidence='external' or @evidence='conjecture']"> <sch:assertÂ test="@cert"> Use the cert attribute when the evidence attribute has the value external or conjecture. </sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element persName
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute cert { text }?,
   attribute evidence { list { ( "internal" | "external" | "conjecture" )+ } }?,
   attribute role { list { ( "cataloguer" | "librarian" | "scribe" )+ } }?,
   attribute ref { list { + } }?,
   text
}

Appendix A.1.82 <placeName>

<placeName> contains an absolute or relative place name. [13.2.3. Place Names]
Modulenamesdates â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
ref(reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Derived fromatt.canonical
StatusRequired
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
model.placeNamePart
Contained by
core: note p q ref

May containCharacter data only
Example
<placeNameÂ ref="http://www.geonames.org/3181928">Bologna</placeName>
Schematronchecks that the ref attribute in the <placeName> element starts with https://www.manuscripta.se/place/
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:placeName"> Â <sch:letÂ name="placename-ref"Â value="substring-after(@ref, 'place/')"/> Â <sch:letÂ name="placename"Â value="doc(concat('../id/place/',$placename-ref,'.xml'))//tei:place/tei:placeName"/> Â <sch:assertÂ test="starts-with(@ref, 'https://www.manuscripta.se/place/')">A URI should be used in the ref attribute for placeName pointing to https://www.manuscripta.se/place/</sch:assert> Â <sch:assertÂ test="$placename = text()">Placename mismatch</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element placeName
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute ref { list { + } },
   text
}

Appendix A.1.83 <provenance>

<provenance> contains any descriptive or other information concerning a single identifiable episode during the history of a manuscript, manuscript part, or other object after its creation but before its acquisition. [10.8. History]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.datable (att.datable.w3c (@when, @notBefore, @notAfter, @from, @to))
Contained by
msdescription: history
May contain
core: bibl date foreign quote
header: idno
msdescription: locus
namesdates: persName placeName
character data
Example
<provenance>At sometime the volume came to <placeNameÂ ref="#Venice"/>, where it came on the market in the <dateÂ notBefore="1692"Â notAfter="1694">late seventeenth century</date>.</provenance>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="bibl"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="date"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="foreign"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

Â Â <elementRefÂ key="persName"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="placeName"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="quote"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>

{

      text
    |Â bibl*
    |Â date*

    |Â persName*
    |Â placeName*
    |Â quote*
   )*

Appendix A.1.85 <publisher>

<publisher> provides the name of the organization responsible for the publication or distribution of a bibliographic item. [3.11.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information 2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc.]
Modulecore â Schema
Contained by
header: publicationStmt
May containCharacter data only
Note

Use the full form of the name by which a company is usually referred to, rather than any abbreviation of it which may appear on a title page

Example
<publicationStmt> Â <publisher>Manuscripta.se: A Digital Catalogue of Manuscripts in Sweden</publisher> Â <dateÂ when="2017"/> Â <availabilityÂ status="free"> Â Â <licenceÂ target="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/">Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International</licence> Â </availability> </publicationStmt>

</content>

Appendix A.1.86 <q>

<q> (quoted) contains material which is distinguished from the surrounding text using quotation marks or a similar method, for any one of a variety of reasons including, but not limited to: direct speech or thought, technical terms or jargon, authorial distance, quotations from elsewhere, and passages that are mentioned but not used. [3.3.3. Quotation]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.global (@xml:id, @n, @xml:lang) (att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp)) (att.global.source (@source)) att.ascribed.directed (@toWhom) (att.ascribed (@who))
typemay be used to indicate whether the offset passage is spoken or thought, or to characterize it more finely.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
spoken
representation of speech
thought
representation of thought, e.g. internal monologue
written
quotation from a written source
soCalled
authorial distance
foreign
distinct
linguistically distinct
term
technical term
emph
rhetorically emphasized
mentioned
refering to itself, not its normal referent
Member of
model.qLike
Contained by
core: head q
May contain
core: add bibl date del desc foreign gap graphic hi lb list listBibl measure note num p q quote ref sic term title unclear
figures: formula
header: idno
msdescription: catchwords depth dimensions height locus locusGrp material msDesc origDate origPlace signatures watermark width
namesdates: country listOrg orgName persName placeName settlement
transcr: ex supplied
character data
Note

May be used to indicate that a passage is distinguished from the surrounding text for reasons concerning which no claim is made. When used in this manner, <q> may be thought of as syntactic sugar for <hi> with a value of rend that indicates the use of such mechanisms as quotation marks.

Example
It is spelled <q>TÃ¼bingen</q> â to enter the letter <q>u</q> with an umlaut hold down the <q>option</q> key and press <q>0 0 f c</q>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element q
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.ascribed.directed.attributes,
   attribute type
   {
      "spoken"
    |Â "thought"
    |Â "written"
    |Â "soCalled"
    |Â "foreign"
    |Â "distinct"
    |Â "term"
    |Â "emph"
    |Â "mentioned"
   }?,
   macro.specialPara
}

Appendix A.1.87 <quote>

<quote> (quotation) contains a phrase or passage attributed by the narrator or author to some agency external to the text. [3.3.3. Quotation 4.3.1. Grouped Texts]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.notated (@notation) att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)

Example
<quoteÂ xml:lang="la">Theodorus samius primo clavem mostravit</quote>

Appendix A.1.88 <ref>

<ref> (reference) defines a reference to another location, possibly modified by additional text or comment. [3.6. Simple Links and Cross-References 16.1. Links]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributes
targetspecifies the destination of the reference by supplying one or more URI References

model.ptrLike
Contained by
core: note p q

Schematronchecks that the target attribute in the <ref> element starts with # or http
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:ref/@target"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="starts-with(., 'http') or starts-with(., '#')">The target value must start with http or #</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Schematronchecks that the <ref> element has a target attribute when it is a child of the <bibl> element
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:bibl/tei:ref"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="@target">The ref element must have a target attribute</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Schematron
<s:reportÂ test="@target and @cRef">Only one of the attributes @target' and @cRef' may be supplied on <s:name/> </s:report>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="bibl"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="date"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="placeName"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="persName"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="watermark"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>

element ref
{
   attribute target { list { + } }?,

}

Appendix A.1.90 <resp/>

<resp/> (responsibility) contains a phrase describing the nature of a person's intellectual responsibility, or an organization's role in the production or distribution of a work. [3.11.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2.2. The Edition Statement 2.2.5. The Series Statement]

Derived fromatt.canonical
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.text
Legal values are:
cataloguer
editor
Contained by
core: respStmt
May containEmpty element
Example
<respStmtÂ xml:id="EN"> Â <persNameÂ ref="#EvaNys"/> Â <respÂ key="cataloguer"/> Â <respÂ key="encoder"/> </respStmt>
Content model

Schema Declaration
element resp { attribute key { "cataloguer" | "editor" }, empty }

Appendix A.1.91 <respStmt>

<respStmt> (statement of responsibility) supplies a statement of responsibility for the intellectual content of a text, edition, recording, or series, where the specialized elements for authors, editors, etc. do not suffice or do not apply. May also be used to encode information about individuals or organizations which have played a role in the production or distribution of a bibliographic work. [3.11.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2.2. The Edition Statement 2.2.5. The Series Statement]
Modulecore â Schema
Contained by
header: titleStmt
May contain
core: resp
namesdates: persName
Example
<respStmtÂ xml:id="EN"> Â <persNameÂ ref="#EvaNys"/> Â <respÂ key="cataloguer"/> Â <respÂ key="encoder"/> </respStmt>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="resp"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="persName"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element respStmt { resp+, persName }

Appendix A.1.93 <rubric>

<rubric> contains the text of any rubric or heading attached to a particular manuscript item, that is, a string of words through which a manuscript or other object signals the beginning of a text division, often with an assertion as to its author and title, which is in some way set off from the text itself, typically in red ink, or by use of different size or type of script, or some other such visual device. [10.6.1. The msItem and msItemStruct Elements]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.msExcerpt (@defective) att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
grc
Greek should be normalized: the first letter of each sentence and of names should be capitalized, iota subscripts should be added, and abbreviations expanded.[Default]
la
sv
Contained by
msdescription: msItem
May contain
core: add del sic
transcr: supplied
character data
Example
<rubricÂ xml:lang="grc"> Â <delÂ xml:lang="grc">á¼ÏÎ»Î·ÏÏÎ¸Î· Ïá½¸ ÏÎ­ÏÎ±ÏÏÎ¿Î½</del> Â <addÂ place="above"Â xml:lang="grc">ÎÎ¯ÏÏÎ½Î¿Ï ÎÎ·ÏÎ±Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¬</add> </rubric>

   ( text | add | del | sic | supplied )*

Appendix A.1.97 <sourceDesc>

<sourceDesc> (source description) describes the source from which an electronic text was derived or generated, typically a bibliographic description in the case of a digitized text, or a phrase such as "born digital" for a text which has no previous existence. [2.2.7. The Source Description]

Appendix A.1.98 <sponsor>

<sponsor> specifies the name of a sponsoring organization or institution. [2.2.1. The Title Statement]
Moduleheader â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.canonical (key, @ref)
Contained by
header: titleStmt
May containCharacter data only
Note

Sponsors give their intellectual authority to a project; they are to be distinguished from funders (see element <funder>), who provide the funding but do not necessarily take intellectual responsibility.

Example
<sponsor>Association for Computers and the Humanities</sponsor> <sponsor>Association for Computational Linguistics</sponsor> <sponsorÂ ref="http://www.allc.org/">Association for Literary and Linguistic Computing</sponsor>
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element sponsor { att.canonical.attribute.ref, text }

Modulemsdescription â Schema

Appendix A.1.100 <supplied>

<supplied> signifies text supplied by the transcriber or editor for any reason; for example because the original cannot be read due to physical damage, or because of an obvious omission by the author or scribe. [11.3.3.1. Damage, Illegibility, and Supplied Text]
Moduletranscr â Schema
AttributesAttributesÂ att.dimensions (@unit, @quantity, @extent) (att.ranging (@atLeast, @atMost, @min, @max)) att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
reasonone or more words indicating why the text has had to be supplied, e.g. overbinding, faded-ink, lost-folio, omitted-in-original.

Contained by
core: q quote title
msdescription: colophon explicit finalRubric foliation incipit rubric
May containCharacter data only
Example
<suppliedÂ xml:lang="grc"Â reason="omitted">Ï</supplied>á¿· ÏÏÎ½ÏÎµÎ»ÎµÏÏá¿
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element supplied
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   att.dimensions.attributes,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   }?,
   attribute reason
   {
      list { ( "omitted" | "illegible" | "damage" | "unknown" )+ }
   },
   text
}

Appendix A.1.101 <support>

<support> contains a description of the materials etc. which make up the physical support for the written part of a manuscript or other object. [10.7.1. Object Description]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
Contained by
msdescription: supportDesc
May contain
core: p
Example
<support> Â <p> Â Â <locusÂ from="14"Â to="24"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â <material>Western paper</material> Â Â <measureÂ type="folding">Quarto</measure> Â Â <dimensionsÂ type="leaf"> Â Â Â <heightÂ quantity="220"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â Â <widthÂ quantity="160"Â unit="mm"/> Â Â </dimensions> Â Â <watermarkÂ n="2a"> Â Â Â <locusGrp> Â Â Â Â <locusÂ from="15"Â to="15"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â Â Â <locusÂ from="20"Â to="20"Â scheme="folios"/> Â Â Â </locusGrp> Â Â Â <termÂ type="watermarkMotif">Hand; SchematronChecks that <support> has <material>
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:support/tei:p"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:locus[following-sibling::tei:material][following-sibling::tei:dimensions[@type='leaf']] or tei:locusGrp[following-sibling::tei:material][following-sibling::tei:dimensions[@type='leaf']]"> The locus, material, and dimensions elements must be used</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model

Â <elementRefÂ key="p"Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
</content>
