Appendix A.1.102 <supportDesc>

<supportDesc> (support description) groups elements describing the physical support for the written part of a manuscript or other object. [10.7.1. Object Description]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
AttributesAttributes
materiala short project-defined name for the material composing the majority of the support
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
paper
parchment
mixed
Contained by
msdescription: objectDesc
May contain
header: extent
msdescription: collation condition foliation support
Schematronchecks that the <supportDesc> element only has a material attribute when it is a descendant of <msPart>
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msPart//tei:supportDesc"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="@material">Use the material attribute for supportDesc for codicological units.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msDesc/tei:physDesc/tei:objectDesc/tei:supportDesc"> Â <sch:reportÂ test="@material">Do not use the material attribute for supportDesc for the bookblock.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="support"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="extent"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="foliation"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="collation"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="condition"Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â </sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element supportDesc
{
   attribute material { "paper" | "parchment" | "mixed" }?,
   ( support?, extent, foliation?, collation?, condition? )
}

Appendix A.1.103 <surface>

<surface> defines a written surface as a two-dimensional coordinate space, optionally grouping one or more graphic representations of that space, zones of interest within that space, and transcriptions of the writing within them. [11.1. Digital Facsimiles 11.2.2. Embedded Transcription]
Moduletranscr â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:id(identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
DatatypeID
Contained by
transcr: facsimile
May contain
core: desc graphic
Example
<surfaceÂ xml:id="UGr-027-1r"> Â <desc>f. 1r</desc> Â <graphicÂ url="UGr-027-0003.jp2"/> </surface>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="desc"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="graphic"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element surface
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   attribute xml:id { text },
   desc,
   graphic
}

Appendix A.1.104 <teiHeader>

<teiHeader> (TEI header) supplies descriptive and declarative metadata associated with a digital resource or set of resources. [2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Moduleheader â Schema
AttributesAttributes
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
en
sv
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
header: fileDesc revisionDesc
Note

One of the few elements unconditionally required in any TEI document.

Example
<teiHeaderÂ xml:lang="en"> Â <fileDesc> Â Â <titleStmt> Â Â Â <title>Uppsala University Library, Gr. 27</title> Â Â Â <respStmtÂ xml:id="EN"> Â Â Â Â <persNameÂ ref="#EvaNys"/> Â Â Â Â <respÂ key="cataloguer"/> Â Â Â Â <respÂ key="encoder"/> Â Â Â </respStmt> Â Â Â <respStmtÂ xml:id="PG"> Â Â Â Â <persNameÂ ref="#PatGra"/> Â Â Â Â <respÂ key="cataloguer"/> Â Â Â Â <respÂ key="encoder"/> Â Â Â </respStmt> Â Â </titleStmt> Â Â <publicationStmt> Â Â Â <publisher>Manuscripta</publisher> Â Â Â <dateÂ when="2016"/> Â Â Â <availabilityÂ status="free"> Â Â Â Â <licenceÂ target="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/">Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International</licence> Â Â Â </availability> Â Â </publicationStmt> Â Â <sourceDesc> <!-- Source description --> Â Â </sourceDesc> Â </fileDesc> </teiHeader>
SchematronCheck that xml:lang with grc is used for Greek characters
<sch:ruleÂ context="//*[not(@xml:lang='grc' or @xml:lang='el')]"> <sch:reportÂ test="text()[matches(., '\p{IsGreek}|\p{IsGreekExtended}')]"> Use the xml:lang="grc" for Ancient Greek text and xml:lang="el" for Modern Greek text </sch:report> </sch:rule>
SchematronChecks that xml:lang with grc is not used for Latin letters or numbers
<sch:ruleÂ context="//*[@xml:lang='grc' or @xml:lang='el']"> <sch:reportÂ test="text()[matches(., '[(\p{N}|\p{L})-[\p{IsGreek}\p{IsGreekExtended}]]')]"> Only characters from Greek and Greek extended chart range are allowed in elements with the xml:lang="grc" or xml:lang="el".</sch:report> </sch:rule>
SchematronCheck for forbidden Greek characters
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="//*[(@xml:lang='grc' or @xml:lang='el')]"> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'Ï')"> Use Greek small letter stigma (U+03DB).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'Ï')"> Use Greek small letter koppa (U+03DF).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'Ï ')"> Use Greek small letter sampi (U+03E1).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'Í¾')"> Use the semicolon (U+003B) for the Greek question mark.</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'Î')"> Use the middle dot (U+00B7) for the Greek semicolon.</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., "'")"> Use the right single quotation mark (U+2019) for the Greek apostrophe.</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½±')"> Use Greek small letter alpha with tonos (U+03AC).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½³')"> Use Greek small letter epsilon with tonos (U+03AD).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½µ')"> Use Greek small letter eta with tonos (U+03AE).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½·')"> Use Greek small letter iota with tonos (U+03AF).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½¹')"> Use Greek small letter omicron with tonos (U+03CC).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½»')"> Use Greek small letter upsilon with tonos (U+03CD).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á½½')"> Use Greek small letter omega with tonos (U+03CE).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á¿')"> Use Greek small letter iota with dialytika and tonos (U+0390).</sch:report> Â <sch:reportÂ test="contains(., 'á¿£')"> Use Greek small letter upsilon with dialytika and tonos (U+03B0).</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
SchematronCheck for the apostrophe U+0027
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="//*[not(@xml:lang='grc' or @xml:lang='el')]"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="not(contains(., "'"))"> Use the right single quotation mark (U+2019) for apostrophe.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
SchematronCheck for the straight double quotation mark (U+0022)
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="text()"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="not(contains(., '"'))"> The use of quotation marks is not allowed. Use the q element instead.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
SchematronCheck for the left single quotation mark (U+2018)
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="text()"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="not(contains(., 'â'))"> The use of quotation marks is not allowed. Use the q element instead.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="fileDesc"Â source="manuscripta.odd#teiHeaderGroup"/>
Â <elementRefÂ key="revisionDesc"Â source="manuscripta.odd#teiHeaderGroup"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element teiHeader
{
   attribute xml:lang { "en" | "sv" },
   fileDesc,
   revisionDesc
}

Appendix A.1.105 <term>

<term> contains a single-word, multi-word, or symbolic designation which is regarded as a technical term. [3.3.4. Terms, Glosses, Equivalents, and Descriptions]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source) att.typed (type, @subtype) att.canonical (key, @ref)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
typecharacterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="//tei:term[@type='proximity']"> <sch:assertÂ test="text()='similar to' or text()='very similar to' or text()='identical with'"> Permitted values are "similar to", "very similar to", or "identical with".</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
layout
proximity
Terms used to describe proximity: "similar to", "very similar to", or "identical with"
script
Description of script
watermarkMotif
Watermark motif, in English
watermarkTerm
Watermark term according to Briquet, in French
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: note p q
header: handNote
msdescription: catchwords decoNote foliation layout musicNotation signatures watermark
May contain
msdescription: material
character data
Example
<termÂ type="watermarkMotif">Hat</term>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="material"/>
Â Â <textNode/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element term
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   att.canonical.attribute.ref,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   }?,
   attribute type
   {
      "layout" | "proximity" | "script" | "watermarkMotif" | "watermarkTerm"
   }?
   >>
   tei:constraintSpec
   [
      ident = "term.proximity"
      scheme = "schematron"
      " "
      """ Permitted values are "similar to", "very similar to", or "identical with"."""
   ],
   ( material | text )*
}

Appendix A.1.106 <text>

<text> contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, for example a poem or drama, a collection of essays, a novel, a dictionary, or a corpus sample. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Moduletextstructure â Schema
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
textstructure: body
Note

This element should not be used to represent a text which is inserted at an arbitrary point within the structure of another, for example as in an embedded or quoted narrative; the <floatingText> is provided for this purpose.

Example
<text> Â <body> Â Â <divÂ xml:id="text_65b"> Â Â Â <head> Â Â Â Â <title>65b: Chronicon breve</title> Â Â Â Â <locusÂ scheme="folios"Â from="283v"Â to="283v"/> Â Â Â </head> Â Â Â <pÂ xml:lang="grc">á½ á¼Î½Î½Î±ÏÎ¿Ï á½ ÏÎ¿ÏÎ»<lb/>ÏÎ± Î Î±Î³Î¹Î¬Î¶Î·ÏÎ· <lb/>á½Ï á¼Ïá¿ÏÎµ ÏÎ· ÎÎµÎ¸ÏÎºÎ¿ÏÏÎ½Î¹. <lb/>Î´Î­ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¿Ï Ïá¼±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿Ï <lb/>á½ Î£ÎµÎ»Î·Î¼Î·Ï á½Ï ÎµÎ´Î¿ÏÎ»ÎµÏÎµ <lb/>Î ÎµÏÏÎ¹Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î£Î¹<lb/>ÏÎ¹Î± á½Î»Î·. <lb/>Î´Î­ÎºÎ±ÏÎ¿Ï ÏÏá¿¶ÏÎ¿Ï <lb/>Ïá¼±ÏÏ ÏÎ¿Ï á½ Î£Î¿ÏÎ»ÎµÎ·Î¼Î±Î½ <lb/>ÏÎ¿ÏÎ»ÏÎ±Î½Î¿Ï á½Ï á¼ÏÎ·ÏÎ±Î¹ <lb/>Ïá½´Î½ Î¡Î¿Î´Î¿ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î±Î»Î¿ÏÎ¹ <lb/>ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïá½´Î½ Îá½Î³ÎºÏÎ¯Î± ÏÎ¿ <lb/>Î± Ï Îº Ï ÎµÏÎ¿Ï á¼ÏÎ¿ Ïá¿¦ <lb/>á¼Î³Î¿ÏÏÏÎ¿Ï ÎºÎ¸ <lb/>... á½ ÏÎ¿Î»ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï</p> Â Â </div> Â </body> </text>
Content model
<content>
Â <elementRefÂ key="body"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element text { body }

Appendix A.1.107 <textLang/>

<textLang/> (text language) describes the languages and writing systems identified within the bibliographic work being described, rather than its description. [3.11.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information 10.6.6. Languages and Writing Systems]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributes
mainLang(main language) supplies a code which identifies the chief language used in the bibliographic work.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
is
(IslÃ¤ndska)
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
non-wes
(West Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-wes).
otherLangs(other languages) one or more codes identifying any other languages used in the bibliographic work.
StatusOptional
Datatype0ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.language separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
is
(IslÃ¤ndska)
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
non-wes
(West Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-wes).
Contained by
msdescription: msContents msItem
May containEmpty element
Note

This element should not be used to document the languages or writing systems used for the bibliographic or manuscript description itself: as for all other TEI elements, such information should be provided by means of the global xml:lang attribute attached to the element containing the description.

In all cases, languages should be identified by means of a standardized âlanguage tagâ generated according to BCP 47. Additional documentation for the language may be provided by a <language> element in the TEI Header.

Example
<textLangÂ mainLang="grc"/>
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element textLang
{
   attribute mainLang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "is"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
    |Â "non-wes"
   },
   attribute otherLangs
   {
      list
      {
         (
            "da"
          |Â "de"
          |Â "el"
          |Â "en"
          |Â "fi"
          |Â "fr"
          |Â "grc"
          |Â "is"
          |Â "it"
          |Â "la"
          |Â "nl"
          |Â "non-dan"
          |Â "non-gut"
          |Â "non-swe"
          |Â "sp"
          |Â "sv"
          |Â "non-wes"
         )*
      }
   }?,
   empty
}

Appendix A.1.108 <title>

<title> contains a title for any kind of work. [3.11.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2.5. The Series Statement]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributesatt.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source) att.typed (type, @subtype)
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.

StatusOptional

Datatypeteidata.text
ref(reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Derived fromatt.canonical
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
typeclassifies the title according to some convenient typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
uniform
(uniform) standardized distinctive title from Pinakes[Default]
alt
(alternate) alternate title by which the work is also known
desc
(descriptive) descriptive paraphrase in English of the work functioning as a title
short
abbreviated form of title
Note

This attribute is provided for convenience in analysing titles and processing them according to their type; where such specialized processing is not necessary, there is no need for such analysis, and the entire title, including subtitles and any parallel titles, may be enclosed within a single <title> element.

Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: bibl item q
header: titleStmt
msdescription: msItem
May contain
core: foreign
namesdates: persName
transcr: supplied
character data
Note

The attributes key and ref, inherited from the class att.canonical may be used to indicate the canonical form for the title; the former, by supplying (for example) the identifier of a record in some external library system; the latter by pointing to an XML element somewhere containing the canonical form of the title.

Example
<titleÂ ref="http://pinakes.irht.cnrs.fr/notices/oeuvre/id/3267"Â type="uniform"Â xml:lang="la">De natura animalium libri XVII</title>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:title/@key"> <sch:reportÂ test="matches(., 'TLG \p{N}') or matches(., 'TLG_\p{N}')"> Do not use space or underscore between TLG and the number </sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="matches(., 'BHG \p{N}') or matches(., 'BHG_\p{N}')"> Do not use space or underscore between BHG and the number </sch:report> <sch:reportÂ test="matches(., 'CPG \p{N}') or matches(., 'CPG_\p{N}')"> Do not use space or underscore between CPG and the number </sch:report> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:msItem/tei:title"> <sch:assertÂ test="@type"> The type attribute must be used </sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="foreign"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="supplied"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="persName"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration
element title
{
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.cert,
   att.global.responsibility.attribute.resp,
   att.global.source.attribute.source,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "da"
    |Â "de"
    |Â "el"
    |Â "en"
    |Â "fi"
    |Â "fr"
    |Â "grc"
    |Â "it"
    |Â "la"
    |Â "nl"
    |Â "non-dan"
    |Â "non-gut"
    |Â "non-swe"
    |Â "sp"
    |Â "sv"
   }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   attribute ref { list { + } }?,
   attribute type { "uniform" | "alt" | "desc" | "short" }?,
   ( text | foreign | supplied | persName )*
}

Appendix A.1.110 <unclear/>

<unclear/> contains a word, phrase, or passage which cannot be transcribed with certainty because it is illegible or inaudible in the source. [11.3.3.1. Damage, Illegibility, and Supplied Text 3.4.3. Additions, Deletions, and Omissions]
Modulecore â Schema
AttributesAttributes
unitnames the unit used for the measurement
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
chars
characters
lines
mm
quantityspecifies the length in the units specified
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
atLeastgives a minimum estimated value for the approximate measurement.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
atMostgives a maximum estimated value for the approximate measurement.
Derived fromatt.ranging
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.numeric
reasonindicates why the material is hard to transcribe.
StatusRequired
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
illegible
<div> Â <head>Rx</head> Â <p>500 mg <unclearÂ reason="illegible">placebo</unclear> Â </p> </div>
Note

One or more words may be used to describe the reason; usually each word will refer to a single cause.

Member of
model.pPart.transcriptional
Contained by
core: foreign q quote
msdescription: colophon explicit finalRubric incipit
May containEmpty element
Example
<gapÂ reason="damage"Â quantity="20"Â unit="mm"/> <unclearÂ reason="illegible"Â quantity="60"Â unit="mm"/> á¼°Î¿ÏÎ´Î¬Î½Î·Ï á¼°Î¿ÏÎ´Î¬Î½Î·Ï á¼°Î¿ÏÎ´Î¬Î½Î¿Ï ÏÎµÎ»<unclearÂ reason="illegible"Â quantity="30"Â unit="mm"/> Î±á¼°Î´Î­ÏÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï, á¼Î¾Î¹Î¿ÏÎ¯Î¼Î·ÏÎ¿Ï
Schematronchecks that the <unclear/> element has either a quantity or atLeast/atMoset attributes.
<sch:pattern> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:unclear"> Â <sch:assertÂ test="@quantity or (@atLeast and @atMost)">The unclear element must have either @quantity or @atLeast/@atMost. </sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
Content model
<content/>
Schema Declaration
element unclear
{
   attribute unit { "chars" | "lines" | "mm" },
   attribute quantity { text }?,
   attribute atLeast { text }?,
   attribute atMost { text }?,
   attribute reason { list { "illegible"+ } },
   empty
}

Appendix A.1.112 <width/>

<width/> contains a measurement of an object along the axis parallel to its bottom, e.g. perpendicular to the spine of a book or codex. [10.3.4. Dimensions]
Modulemsdescription â Schema

Datatypeteidata.enumerated

mm
quantityspecifies the length in the units specified
Derived fromatt.dimensions
StatusOptional

minwhere the measurement summarizes more than one observation or a range, supplies the minimum value observed.

maxwhere the measurement summarizes more than one observation or a range, supplies the maximum value observed.
Derived fromatt.ranging

Datatypeteidata.numeric

   empty

Appendix A.3 Attribute classes

Appendix A.3.1 att.ascribed

att.ascribedÂ provides attributes for elements representing speech or action that can be ascribed to a specific individual. [3.3.3. Quotation 8.3. Elements Unique to Spoken Texts]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersatt.ascribed.directed[q]
AttributesAttributes
whoindicates the person, or group of people, to whom the element content is ascribed.
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
In the following example from Hamlet, speeches (<sp>) in the body of the play are linked to <castItem> elements in the <castList> using the who attribute.
<castItemÂ type="role"> Â <roleÂ xml:id="Barnardo">Bernardo</role> </castItem> <castItemÂ type="role"> Â <roleÂ xml:id="Francisco">Francisco</role> Â <roleDesc>a soldier</roleDesc> </castItem> <!-- ... --> <spÂ who="#Barnardo"> Â <speaker>Bernardo</speaker> Â <lÂ n="1">Who's there?</l> </sp> <spÂ who="#Francisco"> Â <speaker>Francisco</speaker> Â <lÂ n="2">Nay, answer me: stand, and unfold yourself.</l> </sp>
Note

For transcribed speech, this will typically identify a participant or participant group; in other contexts, it will point to any identified <person> element.

Appendix A.3.2 att.ascribed.directed

att.ascribed.directedÂ provides attributes for elements representing speech or action that can be directed at a group or individual. [3.3.3. Quotation 8.3. Elements Unique to Spoken Texts]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersq
AttributesAttributesÂ att.ascribed (@who)
toWhomindicates the person, or group of people, to whom a speech act or action is directed.
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
In the following example from Mary Pix's The False Friend, speeches (<sp>) in the body of the play are linked to <castItem> elements in the <castList> using the toWhom attribute, which is used to specify who the speech is directed to. Additionally, the <stage> includes toWhom to indicate the directionality of the action.
<castItemÂ type="role"> Â <roleÂ xml:id="emil">Emilius.</role> </castItem> <castItemÂ type="role"> Â <roleÂ xml:id="lov">Lovisa</role> </castItem> <castItemÂ type="role"> Â <roleÂ xml:id="serv">A servant</role> </castItem> <!-- ... --> <spÂ who="#emil" Â toWhom="#lov"> Â <speaker>Emil.</speaker> Â <lÂ n="1">My love!</l> </sp> <spÂ who="#lov" Â toWhom="#emil"> Â <speaker>Lov.</speaker> Â <lÂ n="2">I have no Witness of my Noble Birth</l> Â <stageÂ who="emil" Â Â toWhom="#serv">Pointing to her Woman.</stage> Â <l>But that poor helpless wretchââ</l> </sp>
Note

To indicate the recipient of written correspondence, use the elements used in section 2.4.6. Correspondence Description, rather than a toWhom attribute.

Appendix A.3.3 att.canonical

att.canonicalÂ provides attributes which can be used to associate a representation such as a name or title with canonical information about the object being named or referenced. [13.1.1. Linking Names and Their Referents]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersatt.naming[att.personal] date
AttributesAttributes
keyprovides an externally-defined means of identifying the entity (or entities) being named, using a coded value of some kind.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.text
<author> Â <nameÂ key="name 427308" Â Â type="organisation">[New Zealand Parliament, Legislative Council]</name> </author>
<author> Â <nameÂ key="Hugo, Victor (1802-1885)" Â Â ref="http://www.idref.fr/026927608">Victor Hugo</name> </author>
Note

The value may be a unique identifier from a database, or any other externally-defined string identifying the referent.

No particular syntax is proposed for the values of the key attribute, since its form will depend entirely on practice within a given project. For the same reason, this attribute is not recommended in data interchange, since there is no way of ensuring that the values used by one project are distinct from those used by another. In such a situation, a preferable approach for magic tokens which follows standard practice on the Web is to use a ref attribute whose value is a tag URI as defined in RFC 4151.

ref(reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
<nameÂ ref="http://viaf.org/viaf/109557338" Â type="person">Seamus Heaney</name>
Note

The value must point directly to one or more XML elements or other resources by means of one or more URIs, separated by whitespace. If more than one is supplied the implication is that the name identifies several distinct entities.

Appendix A.3.4 att.citing

att.citingÂ provides attributes for specifying the specific part of a bibliographic item being cited. [1.3.1. Attribute Classes]
Moduletei â Schema
MemberscitedRange
AttributesAttributes
unitidentifies the unit of information conveyed by the element, e.g. columns, pages, volume, entry.
StatusRecommended
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
volume
issue
page
footnote
line
chapter
column
folio
plate
number
Use e.g. for RGK numbers or ruling patterns i Leroy-Sautel
fromspecifies the starting point of the range of units indicated by the unit attribute.
StatusRecommended
Datatypeteidata.word
tospecifies the end-point of the range of units indicated by the unit attribute.
StatusRecommended
Datatypeteidata.word

Appendix A.3.5 att.datable

att.datableÂ provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain dates, times, or datable events. [3.5.4. Dates and Times 13.3.7. Dates and Times]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersacquisition binding date origDate provenance
AttributesAttributesÂ att.datable.w3c (@when, @notBefore, @notAfter, @from, @to)
Note

This âsuperclassâ provides attributes that can be used to provide normalized values of temporal information. By default, the attributes from the att.datable.w3c class are provided. If the module for names & dates is loaded, this class also provides attributes from the att.datable.iso and att.datable.custom classes. In general, the possible values of attributes restricted to the W3C datatypes form a subset of those values available via the ISO 8601 standard. However, the greater expressiveness of the ISO datatypes may not be needed, and there exists much greater software support for the W3C datatypes.

Appendix A.3.6 att.datable.w3c

att.datable.w3cÂ provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain datable events conforming to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition. [3.5.4. Dates and Times 13.3.7. Dates and Times]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersatt.datable[acquisition binding date origDate provenance]
AttributesAttributes
whensupplies the value of the date or time in a standard form, e.g. yyyy-mm-dd.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.temporal.w3c
Examples of W3C date, time, and date & time formats.
<p> Â <dateÂ when="1945-10-24">24 Oct 45</date> Â <dateÂ when="1996-09-24T07:25:00Z">September 24th, 1996 at 3:25 in the morning</date> Â <timeÂ when="1999-01-04T20:42:00-05:00">Jan 4 1999 at 8 pm</time> Â <timeÂ when="14:12:38">fourteen twelve and 38 seconds</time> Â <dateÂ when="1962-10">October of 1962</date> Â <dateÂ when="--06-12">June 12th</date> Â <dateÂ when="---01">the first of the month</date> Â <dateÂ when="--08">August</date> Â <dateÂ when="2006">MMVI</date> Â <dateÂ when="0056">AD 56</date> Â <dateÂ when="-0056">56 BC</date> </p>
This list begins in the year 1632, more precisely on Trinity Sunday, i.e. the Sunday after Pentecost, in that year the <dateÂ calendar="#julian" Â when="1632-06-06">27th of May (old style)</date>.
<opener> Â <dateline> Â Â <placeName>Dorchester, Village,</placeName> Â Â <dateÂ when="1828-03-02">March 2d. 1828.</date> Â </dateline> Â <salute>To Â Â  Mrs. Cornell,</salute> Sunday <timeÂ when="12:00:00">noon.</time> </opener>
notBeforespecifies the earliest possible date for the event in standard form, e.g. yyyy-mm-dd.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.temporal.w3c
notAfterspecifies the latest possible date for the event in standard form, e.g. yyyy-mm-dd.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.temporal.w3c
fromindicates the starting point of the period in standard form, e.g. yyyy-mm-dd.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.temporal.w3c
toindicates the ending point of the period in standard form, e.g. yyyy-mm-dd.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.temporal.w3c
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@when]"> <sch:reportÂ test="@notBefore|@notAfter|@from|@to"Â role="nonfatal">The @when attribute cannot be used with any other att.datable.w3c attributes.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@from]"> <sch:reportÂ test="@notBefore"Â role="nonfatal">The @from and @notBefore attributes cannot be used together.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@to]"> <sch:reportÂ test="@notAfter"Â role="nonfatal">The @to and @notAfter attributes cannot be used together.</sch:report> </sch:rule>
Example
<dateÂ from="1863-05-28"Â to="1863-06-01">28 May through 1 June 1863</date>
Note

The value of these attributes should be a normalized representation of the date, time, or combined date & time intended, in any of the standard formats specified by XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition, using the Gregorian calendar.

The most commonly-encountered format for the date portion of a temporal attribute is yyyy-mm-dd, but yyyy, --mm, ---dd, yyyy-mm, or --mm-dd may also be used. For the time part, the form hh:mm:ss is used.

Note that this format does not currently permit use of the value 0000 to represent the year 1 BCE; instead the value -0001 should be used.

Appendix A.3.7 att.dimensions

att.dimensionsÂ provides attributes for describing the size of physical objects.
Moduletei â Schema

AttributesAttributesÂ att.ranging (@atLeast, @atMost, @min, @max)
unitnames the unit used for the measurement
StatusOptional

Legal values are:
mm
millimeters
chars
characters
lines

<gapÂ extent="5 words"/>
<heightÂ extent="half the page"/>

Appendix A.3.8 att.global

att.globalÂ provides attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1. Global Attributes]
Moduletei â Schema
MembersorigDate origPlace q
AttributesAttributesÂ att.global.responsibility (@cert, @resp) att.global.source (@source)
xml:id(identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
StatusOptional
DatatypeID
Note

The xml:id attribute may be used to specify a canonical reference for an element; see section 3.10. Reference Systems.

n(number) gives a number (or other label) for an element, which is not necessarily unique within the document.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.text
Note

The value of this attribute is always understood to be a single token, even if it contains space or other punctuation characters, and need not be composed of numbers only. It is typically used to specify the numbering of chapters, sections, list items, etc.; it may also be used in the specification of a standard reference system for the text.

xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.language
Legal values are:
da
(Danish)
de
(German)
el
(Modern Greek)
en
(English)
fi
(Finnish)
fr
(French)
grc
(Ancient Greek (to 1453))
it
(Italian)
la
(Latin)
nl
(Dutch)
non-dan
(Old Danish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-dan).
non-gut
(Old Gutnish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-gut).
non-swe
(Old Swedish of East Norse) LINGUIST List code standard (http://multitree.org/codes/non-swe).
sp
(Spanish)
sv
(Swedish)
<p> â¦ The consequences of this rapid depopulation were the loss of the last <foreignÂ xml:lang="rap">ariki</foreign> or chief (Routledge 1920:205,210) and their connections to ancestral territorial organization.</p>
Note

The xml:lang value will be inherited from the immediately enclosing element, or from its parent, and so on up the document hierarchy. It is generally good practice to specify xml:lang at the highest appropriate level, noticing that a different default may be needed for the teiHeader from that needed for the associated resource element or elements, and that a single TEI document may contain texts in many languages.

The authoritative list of registered language subtags is maintained by IANA and is available at http://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry. For a good general overview of the construction of language tags, see http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/, and for a practical step-by-step guide, see https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags.en.php.

The value used must conform with BCP 47. If the value is a private use code (i.e., starts with x- or contains -x-), a <language> element with a matching value for its ident attribute should be supplied in the TEI header to document this value. Such documentation may also optionally be supplied for non-private-use codes, though these must remain consistent with their (IETF)Internet Engineering Task Force definitions.

Appendix A.3.9 att.global.responsibility

att.global.responsibilityÂ provides attributes indicating the agent responsible for some aspect of the text, the markup or something asserted by the markup, and the degree of certainty associated with it. [1.3.1.1.4. Sources, certainty, and responsibility 3.4. Simple Editorial Changes 11.3.2.2. Hand, Responsibility, and Certainty Attributes 17.3. Spans and Interpretations 13.1.1. Linking Names and Their Referents]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersatt.global[origDate origPlace q] provenance
AttributesAttributes
cert(certainty) signifies the degree of certainty associated with the intervention or interpretation.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.probCert
resp(responsible party) indicates the agency responsible for the intervention or interpretation, for example an editor or transcriber.
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Note

To reduce the ambiguity of a resp pointing directly to a person or organization, we recommend that resp be used to point not to an agent (<person> or <org>) but to a <respStmt>, <author>, <editor> or similar element which clarifies the exact role played by the agent. Pointing to multiple <respStmt>s allows the encoder to specify clearly each of the roles played in part of a TEI file (creating, transcribing, encoding, editing, proofing etc.).

Example
Blessed are the <choice> Â <sic>cheesemakers</sic> Â <corrÂ resp="#editor"Â cert="high">peacemakers</corr> </choice>: for they shall be called the children of God.
Example
<!-- in the <text> ... --><lg> <!-- ... --> Â <l>Punkes, Panders, baÅ¿e extortionizing Â Â  sla<choice> Â Â Â <sic>n</sic> Â Â Â <corrÂ resp="#JENS1_transcriber">u</corr> Â Â </choice>es,</l> <!-- ... --> </lg> <!-- in the <teiHeader> ... --> <!-- ... --> <respStmtÂ xml:id="JENS1_transcriber"> Â <respÂ when="2014">Transcriber</resp> Â <name>Janelle Jenstad</name> </respStmt>

Appendix A.3.10 att.global.source

att.global.sourceÂ provides an attribute used by elements to point to an external source. [1.3.1.1.4. Sources, certainty, and responsibility 3.3.3. Quotation 8.3.4. Writing]
Moduletei â Schema
Membersatt.global[origDate origPlace q]
AttributesAttributes
sourcespecifies the source from which some aspect of this element is drawn.
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Note

The source attribute points to an external source. When used on elements describing schema components such as <schemaSpec> or <moduleRef> it identifies the source from which declarations for the components of the object being defined may be obtained.

On other elements it provides a pointer to the bibliographical source from which a quotation or citation is drawn.

In either case, the location may be provided using any form of URI, for example an absolute URI, a relative URI, or private scheme URI that is expanded to an absolute URI as documented in a <prefixDef>.

If more than one location is specified, the default assumption is that the required source should be obtained by combining the resources indicated.

Example
<p> <!-- ... --> As Willard McCarty (<biblÂ xml:id="mcc_2012">2012, p.2</bibl>) tells us, <quoteÂ source="#mcc_2012">âCollaborationâ is a problematic and should be a contested Â Â  term.</quote> <!-- ... --> </p>
Example
<p> <!-- ... --> Â <quoteÂ source="#chicago_15_ed">Grammatical theories are in flux, and the more we learn, the Â Â  less we seem to know.</quote> <!-- ... --> </p> <!-- ... --> <biblÂ xml:id="chicago_15_ed"> Â <titleÂ level="m">The Chicago Manual of Style</title>, <edition>15th edition</edition>. <pubPlace>Chicago</pubPlace>: <publisher>University of Â Â  Chicago Press</publisher> (<date>2003</date>), <biblScopeÂ unit="page">p.147</biblScope>. </bibl>
Example
<elementRefÂ key="p"Â source="tei:2.0.1"/>
Include in the schema an element named <p> available from the TEI P5 2.0.1 release.
Example
<schemaSpecÂ ident="myODD"Â source="mycompiledODD.xml"> <!-- further declarations specifying the components required --> </schemaSpec>
Create a schema using components taken from the file mycompiledODD.xml.

Appendix A.3.12 att.msExcerpt

att.msExcerptÂ (manuscript excerpt) provides attributes used to describe excerpts from a manuscript placed in a description thereof. [10.6. Intellectual Content]
Modulemsdescription â Schema
Memberscolophon finalRubric rubric
AttributesAttributes
defectiveindicates whether the passage being quoted is defective, i.e. incomplete through loss or damage.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.xTruthValue
Note

In the case of an incipit, indicates whether the incipit as given is defective, i.e. the first words of the text as preserved, as opposed to the first words of the work itself. In the case of an explicit, indicates whether the explicit as given is defective, i.e. the final words of the text as preserved, as opposed to what the closing words would have been had the text of the work been whole.

Appendix A.3.17 att.typed

att.typedÂ provides attributes which can be used to classify or subclassify elements in any way. [1.3.1. Attribute Classes 17.1.1. Words and Above 3.5.1. Referring Strings 3.6. Simple Links and Cross-References 3.5.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions 3.12.1. Core Tags for Verse 7.2.5. Speech Contents 4.1.1. Un-numbered Divisions 4.1.2. Numbered Divisions 4.2.1. Headings and Trailers 4.4. Virtual Divisions 13.3.2.3. Personal Relationships 11.3.1.1. Core Elements for Transcriptional Work 16.1.1. Pointers and Links 16.3. Blocks, Segments, and Anchors 12.2. <divÂ type="verse"> Â <head>Night in Tarras</head> Â <lgÂ type="stanza"> Â Â <l>At evening tramping on the hot white road</l> Â Â <l>â¦</l> Â </lg> Â <lgÂ type="stanza"> Â Â <l>A wind sprang up from nowhere as the sky</l> Â Â <l>â¦</l> Â </lg> </div>
Note

The type attribute is present on a number of elements, not all of which are members of att.typed, usually because these elements restrict the possible values for the attribute in a specific way.

subtypeprovides a sub-categorization of the element, if needed

Schematron

Note

When appropriate, values from an established typology should be used. Alternatively a typology may be defined in the associated TEI header. If values are to be taken from a project-specific list, this should be defined using the <valList> element in the project-specific schema description, as described in 23.3.1.4. Modification of Attribute and Attribute Value Lists .

Appendix A.4 Macros

Appendix A.5 Datatypes

Appendix A.5.1 teidata.certainty

teidata.certaintyÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a degree of certainty.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model
<content>
Â <valListÂ type="closed">
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="high"/>
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="medium"/>
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="low"/>
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="unknown"/>
Â </valList>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.certainty = "high" | "medium" | "low" | "unknown"
Note

Certainty may be expressed by one of the predefined symbolic values high, medium, or low. The value unknown should be used in cases where the encoder does not wish to assert an opinion about the matter.

Appendix A.5.2 teidata.count

teidata.countÂ defines the range of attribute values used for a non-negative integer value used as a count.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by

  • layout/@columns
  • layout/@ruledLines
  • layout/@writtenLines

<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="nonNegativeInteger"/>
</content>

teidata.count = xsd:nonNegativeInteger
Note

Any positive integer value or zero is permitted

Appendix A.5.3 teidata.enumerated

teidata.enumeratedÂ defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • add/@place
  • availability/@status
  • change/@status
  • decoNote/@type
  • depth/@unit
  • dimensions/@type
  • filiation/@type
  • gap/@unit
  • gap/@reason
  • height/@unit
  • idno/@type
  • idno/@subtype

  • measure/@type
  • num/@type
  • objectDesc/@form

  • persName/@role

  • revisionDesc/@status
  • supportDesc/@material
  • term/@type
  • title/@type
  • unclear/@unit
  • unclear/@reason
  • width/@unit
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.word"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.enumerated = teidata.word
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single âwordâ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

Typically, the list of documented possibilities will be provided (or exemplified) by a value list in the associated attribute specification, expressed with a <valList> element.

Appendix A.5.4 teidata.language

teidata.languageÂ defines the range of attribute values used to identify a particular combination of human language and writing system. [6.1. Language Identification]
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • add/@xml:lang
  • colophon/@xml:lang
  • del/@xml:lang
  • ex/@xml:lang
  • explicit/@xml:lang
  • finalRubric/@xml:lang
  • foreign/@xml:lang
  • incipit/@xml:lang
  • msDesc/@xml:lang
  • msName/@xml:lang
  • num/@xml:lang
  • p/@xml:lang
  • quote/@xml:lang
  • rubric/@xml:lang
  • sic/@xml:lang
  • supplied/@xml:lang
  • teiHeader/@xml:lang
  • term/@xml:lang
  • textLang/@mainLang
  • textLang/@otherLangs
  • title/@xml:lang
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="language"/>
Â Â <valList>
Â Â Â <valItemÂ ident=""/>
Â Â </valList>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.language = xsd:language | ( "" )
Note

The values for this attribute are language âtagsâ as defined in BCP 47. Currently BCP 47 comprises RFC 5646 and RFC 4647; over time, other IETF documents may succeed these as the best current practice.

A âlanguage tagâ, per BCP 47, is assembled from a sequence of components or subtags separated by the hyphen character (-, U+002D). The tag is made of the following subtags, in the following order. Every subtag except the first is optional. If present, each occurs only once, except the fourth and fifth components (variant and extension), which are repeatable.

language
The IANA-registered code for the language. This is almost always the same as the ISO 639 2-letter language code if there is one. The list of available registered language subtags can be found at http://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry. It is recommended that this code be written in lower case.
script
The ISO 15924 code for the script. These codes consist of 4 letters, and it is recommended they be written with an initial capital, the other three letters in lower case. The canonical list of codes is maintained by the Unicode Consortium, and is available at http://unicode.org/iso15924/iso15924-codes.html. The IETF recommends this code be omitted unless it is necessary to make a distinction you need.
region
Either an ISO 3166 country code or a UN M.49 region code that is registered with IANA (not all such codes are registered, e.g. UN codes for economic groupings or codes for countries for which there is already an ISO 3166 2-letter code are not registered). The former consist of 2 letters, and it is recommended they be written in upper case; the list of codes can be searched or browsed at https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#search/code/. The latter consist of 3 digits; the list of codes can be found at http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm.
variant
An IANA-registered variation. These codes are used to indicate additional, well-recognized variations that define a language or its dialects that are not covered by other available subtags.
extension
An extension has the format of a single letter followed by a hyphen followed by additional subtags. These exist to allow for future extension to BCP 47, but as of this writing no such extensions are in use.
private use
An extension that uses the initial subtag of the single letter x (i.e., starts with x-) has no meaning except as negotiated among the parties involved. These should be used with great care, since they interfere with the interoperability that use of RFC 4646 is intended to promote. In order for a document that makes use of these subtags to be TEI-conformant, a corresponding <language> element must be present in the TEI header.

There are two exceptions to the above format. First, there are language tags in the IANA registry that do not match the above syntax, but are present because they have been âgrandfatheredâ from previous specifications.

Second, an entire language tag can consist of only a private use subtag. These tags start with x-, and do not need to follow any further rules established by the IETF and endorsed by these Guidelines. Like all language tags that make use of private use subtags, the language in question must be documented in a corresponding <language> element in the TEI header.

Examples include

sn
Shona
zh-TW
Taiwanese
zh-Hant-HK
Chinese written in traditional script as used in Hong Kong
en-SL
English as spoken in Sierra Leone
pl
Polish
es-MX
Spanish as spoken in Mexico
es-419
Spanish as spoken in Latin America

The W3C Internationalization Activity has published a useful introduction to BCP 47, Language tags in HTML and XML.

Appendix A.5.5 teidata.numeric

teidata.numericÂ defines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • depth/@quantity
  • depth/@min
  • depth/@max
  • gap/@quantity
  • gap/@atLeast
  • gap/@atMost
  • height/@quantity
  • height/@min
  • height/@max
  • measure/@quantity
  • num/@value
  • unclear/@quantity
  • unclear/@atLeast
  • unclear/@atMost
  • width/@quantity
  • width/@min
  • width/@max
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="double"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="token"Â restriction="(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="decimal"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.numeric =
   xsd:double | token { pattern = "(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)" } | xsd:decimal
Note

Any numeric value, represented as a decimal number, in floating point format, or as a ratio.

To represent a floating point number, expressed in scientific notation, âE notationâ, a variant of âexponential notationâ, may be used. In this format, the value is expressed as two numbers separated by the letter E. The first number, the significand (sometimes called the mantissa) is given in decimal format, while the second is an integer. The value is obtained by multiplying the mantissa by 10 the number of times indicated by the integer. Thus the value represented in decimal notation as 1000.0 might be represented in scientific notation as 10E3.

A value expressed as a ratio is represented by two integer values separated by a solidus (/) character. Thus, the value represented in decimal notation as 0.5 might be represented as a ratio by the string 1/2.

Appendix A.5.6 teidata.outputMeasurement

teidata.outputMeasurementÂ defines a range of values for use in specifying the size of an object that is intended for display.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"Â restriction="[\-+]?\d+(\.\d+)?(%|cm|mm|in|pt|pc|px|em|ex|gd|rem|vw|vh|vm)"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.outputMeasurement =
   token
   {
      pattern = "[\-+]?\d+(\.\d+)?(%|cm|mm|in|pt|pc|px|em|ex|gd|rem|vw|vh|vm)"
   }
Example
<figure> Â <head>The TEI Logo</head> Â <figDesc>Stylized yellow angle brackets with the letters <mentioned>TEI</mentioned> in Â Â  between and <mentioned>text encoding initiative</mentioned> underneath, all on a white Â Â  background.</figDesc> Â <graphicÂ height="600px"Â width="600px"Â url="http://www.tei-c.org/logos/TEI-600.jpg"/> </figure>
Note

These values map directly onto the values used by XSL-FO and CSS. For definitions of the units see those specifications; at the time of this writing the most complete list is in the CSS3 working draft.

Appendix A.5.7 teidata.pointer

teidata.pointerÂ defines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • change/@who
  • country/@ref
  • institution/@ref
  • licence/@target
  • locus/@scheme
  • msDesc/@resp
  • msItem/@class
  • persName/@ref
  • placeName/@ref
  • ref/@target
  • repository/@ref
  • settlement/@ref
  • title/@ref
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="anyURI"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.pointer = xsd:anyURI
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax. Note that the values themselves are encoded using RFC 3987 Internationalized Resource Identifiers (IRIs) mapping to URIs. For example, https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/% is encoded as https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/%25 while http://ÙÙÙØ¹.ÙØ²Ø§Ø±Ø©-Ø§ÙØ§ØªØµØ§ÙØ§Øª.ÙØµØ±/ is encoded as http://xn--4gbrim.xn----rmckbbajlc6dj7bxne2c.xn--wgbh1c/

Appendix A.5.8 teidata.probCert

teidata.probCertÂ defines a range of attribute values which can be expressed either as a numeric probability or as a coded certainty value.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • persName/@cert
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.probability"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.certainty"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.probCert = teidata.probability | teidata.certainty

Appendix A.5.9 teidata.probability

teidata.probabilityÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a probability.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="double"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.probability = xsd:double
Note

Probability is expressed as a real number between 0 and 1; 0 representing certainly false and 1 representing certainly true.

Appendix A.5.10 teidata.temporal.w3c

teidata.temporal.w3cÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition specification.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • change/@when
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="date"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gYear"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gMonth"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gDay"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gYearMonth"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gMonthDay"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="time"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="dateTime"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.temporal.w3c =
   xsd:date
 |Â xsd:gYear
 |Â xsd:gMonth
 |Â xsd:gDay
 |Â xsd:gYearMonth
 |Â xsd:gMonthDay
 |Â xsd:time
 |Â xsd:dateTime
Note

If it is likely that the value used is to be compared with another, then a time zone indicator should always be included, and only the dateTime representation should be used.

Appendix A.5.11 teidata.text

teidata.textÂ defines the range of attribute values used to express some kind of identifying string as a single sequence of unicode characters possibly including whitespace.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • resp/@key
  • title/@key
  • watermark/@n
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="string"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.text = string
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single âtokenâ in which whitespace and other punctuation characters are permitted.

Appendix A.5.12 teidata.version

teidata.versionÂ defines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • TEI/@version
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"Â restriction="[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.version = token { pattern = "[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}" }
Note

The value of this attribute follows the pattern specified by the Unicode consortium for its version number (http://unicode.org/versions/). A version number contains digits and fullstop characters only. The first number supplied identifies the major version number. A second and third number, for minor and sub-minor version numbers, may also be supplied.

Appendix A.5.13 teidata.word

teidata.wordÂ defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single word or token.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
teidata.enumeratedElement:
  • locus/@from
  • locus/@to
  • supplied/@reason
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"Â restriction="(\p{L}|\p{N}|\p{P}|\p{S})+"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.word = token { pattern = "(\p{L}|\p{N}|\p{P}|\p{S})+" }
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single âwordâ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

Appendix A.5.14 teidata.xTruthValue

teidata.xTruthValueÂ (extended truth value) defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value which may be unknown.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Element:
  • binding/@contemporary
  • explicit/@defective
  • incipit/@defective
  • msItem/@defective
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="boolean"/>
Â Â <valList>
Â Â Â <valItemÂ ident="unknown"/>
Â Â Â <valItemÂ ident="inapplicable"/>
Â Â </valList>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.xTruthValue = xsd:boolean | ( "unknown" | "inapplicable" )
Note

In cases where where uncertainty is inappropriate, use the datatype data.TruthValue.

Appendix A.5.15 teidata.xpath

teidata.xpathÂ defines attribute values which contain an XPath expression.
Moduletei â Schema
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.xpath = text
Note

Any XPath expression using the syntax defined in [[undefined XSLT2]].

When writing programs that evaluate XPath expressions, programmers should be mindful of the possibility of malicious code injection attacks. For further information about XPath injection attacks, see the article at OWASP.
